KOOTENAY INDIAN SCHOOL
CRANBROOK, B.C.

Jan. 10 /49.

Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have had the good fortune of employing a night-watchman for our school beginning the first of January. If my memory serves me right it seems possible that we can get not only assistance in paying his salary but also that the Dept. will install time-clocks to insure careful guardianship of the building during the night hours. For our school I think two clocks would be sufficient, one in the engine-room and one on the main floor. If it is possible to have these supplied I would be pleased to receive them. Would you also inform us as to the proper procedure regarding the salary and the amount allowed by the Dept.

Sincerely Yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.
MEMORANDUM

Re: St. Joseph's Creek Pipeline - Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

Further to our memorandum of December 24th we have received the memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs dated January 4, 1949 in which we are advised that a transfer of $200.00 will be made to complete the work on the St. Joseph's Creek pipeline at Kootenay Residential School.

We have not, however, yet received approval from you to accept the offer of Messrs. Patmore Brothers of Cranbrook, B.C. to complete the pipework inside the school at a cost of $560.00. This matter appears to be urgent as it will take this Firm about two months to obtain the necessary material and we would like to have the installation completed during the present fiscal year.

Could we now please have approval to accept this tender.

Chief Engineer.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, January 14, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

For some years past, we have provided an amount in our estimates in order to make an allowance towards the salary of night watchmen at certain of our Indian Residential Schools which we consider are not fireproof. The usual allowance is for a period of seven months at $60. a month.

From time to time some officials have expressed the opinion that an allowance for night watchmen should be paid at all Government-owned Residential Schools.

We have just received a request for an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman at the Kootenay School at which school we have not previously made any allowance. We are aware that practically all our schools employ a special night watchman during the heating season and we feel that it would be in the best interest of all parties concerned for the Department to allow a grant towards the salary of the night watchman at these schools at which no allowance is made at the present time.

I would appreciate having your approval.

Director.

PP/RM.
AIR MAIL

29th January, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

We recently received a request from the Principal of the Kootenay Residential School for an allowance towards the salary of the night watchmen, effective 1st January, 1949.

For several years past we have been allowing a grant towards the salary of a night watchman for the period October to the following April at those Schools where we considered a definite fire hazard existed. The schools at which this allowance is being paid were selected some years ago, and no recent additions have been made to the list. As a matter of fact, we are not making any allowance towards the salary of a night watchman at any of the Government-owned Residential Schools in the province of British Columbia.

When we received the Principal's request, we submitted a memorandum to the Deputy Minister asking his opinion regarding the payment of an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman. His reply was as follows:

(1) Allowance must not be paid to a present member of the staff.
(2) Allowance must be paid only to schools which are certified by an engineer as subject to special danger by fire.

In the case of the Kootenay Residential School, I note the following statement contained in the report submitted to us by Donald Inspection Limited in connection with their inspection of the Kootenay Residential School on 11th September, 1948:

......2
"In addition to this, there should also be an elevated water tank of not less than 20,000 gallons capacity. At present a small air pump pumps pressure to a tank which has been buried in the ground. So long as it is only used for domestic purposes there should be no trouble, but should you have a fire and any quantity of water is taken from this tank, the pressure is dropped and no water will be available for fire fighting purposes."

In view of this report which was made by an engineer, it would appear that the Kootenay Residential School might be considered as one at which an allowance could be made towards the salary of the night watchman during the months mentioned in the first part of my letter.

However, when we allow a grant for a night watchman at one school, we generally receive similar requests from other schools; and consequently before replying to the Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, we would like to have your comments and at the same time, you might state if you consider there are any other Government-owned schools in British Columbia at which any such allowance should be made, keeping in mind the conditions laid down by the Deputy Minister.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Meary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Re: Water Supply,
St. Joseph's Creek Pipeline,
Kootenay I.R.S.,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Ottawa, February 19, 1949.

Further to our memorandum of February 15th with which were forwarded duplicate copies of a report by Mr. A.H. Perry of the Public Health Engineering Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare, Vancouver, B.C., we have received the following from Mr. Cornish which deals with this report of Mr. Perry and gives a little more information:

"The only proposed uses of unchlorinated creek water not covered in the report are for feeding stock in the barn and for cooling milk in the dairy. Untreated creek water is now used for these purposes. I understand that there is no objection from a public health point of view to use polluted water for feeding stock; that is, no pollution can be carried from the drinking water to the milk. However, such water should not be used for cleansing cows and precautions will need to be taken on that point. At present there are several exposed taps in the barn and these are to be eliminated if possible otherwise reduced to the essential minimum and marked. The troughs for cooling water should have covers with holes through which the milk cans are inserted so that there is no exposed water surface. It should be borne in mind that the installation to supply creek water to the barn and dairy are to be made by school authorities and that this Division will not be responsible for such work."

Indian Affairs are advised to see that the recommendations of Mr. Perry and Mr. Cornish are carried out in order that the contaminated water from St. Joseph's Creek shall not be used in its raw state in a manner which might affect the health of those using it.

A.M.
Chief Engineer.

Dear Bernard:

Since my visit to Ottawa I have been to the Kootenay Indian Residential school at Cranbrook and had quite a chat with the Sisters and Principal, Rev. Father Kelly. The main topic of conversation was, of course, the possibility of having this school connected with the East Kootenay Power line at the Wasa substation.

You will recall that in our Estimates we have the sum of $8,100 for this purpose, together with an item for $2,000 to effect the minor improvements to the school wiring, etc. I really feel it is imperative that the school get the benefit of East Kootenay Power. The present arrangements for ironing, which are really pathetic, should be replaced and other electrical services which are not possible under the present system provided. I am quite sure we can utilize the present diesel engine which generates power at present to good advantage elsewhere.

This letter is merely to remind you of this matter and in the hope that it will remain in the Estimates and enable us to go ahead with this much needed improvement at as early a date as possible.

With kindest personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Bernard F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
9th March, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of 1st March, 1949, with reference to electricity for the Kootenay Residential School.

For your personal information I may say that we included an amount of $10,000.00 in the main appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50 for the purpose mentioned. Our estimates have not yet been approved by Parliament, but I feel certain that the amount will be allowed.

However, on reviewing our file, I found your letter of 28th August, 1948, enclosing a copy of a letter addressed to Superintendent Dunn from the East Kootenay Power Company, Limited. In your letter you recommend a three phase line on which the power company quoted a price of $10,893.20 and as a matter of fact, this amount was not a firm bid.

We note from your letter of 1st March, 1949, that you estimate the cost of the improvements to the school wiring to be $2,000.00. On the prices quoted the total expenditure would be approximately $13,000.00. It is our intention to make every effort to secure the additional amount over and above what has already been provided in the appropriation, but in the meantime, I think it would be to our mutual advantage if you could secure the following information:

......2
1. Another quotation from the East Kootenay Power Company, giving a firm bid if possible on the cost of supplying a three phase line to the Kootenay School.

2. A quotation from two or more reliable electricians, tendering on the electrical work required to effect the necessary improvements to the school wiring.

It is possible that Mr. Webb of the Lands and Development Services Branch has already made some enquiries along the above lines, as following receipt of the Donald Inspection Company report on the Kootenay School, we wrote to the Lands and Development Services Branch. We are not certain if the Head Office here have written to Mr. Webb.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of January 29th, 1949, File 884-5 (E.1) regarding the proposed payment of an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman at the Kootenay Residential School, a review of our file indicates that this matter was the subject of previous correspondence, reference Mr. Phelan's letter of March 19th, 1946, at which time the Department approved payment of $40.00 per month during the period November 1st, 1945, to April 30th, 1946.

It is felt that payment of the amount should be continued, at least until the conditions referred to by the Engineer which make the School subject to special danger by fire, are remedied.

District School Inspector Davey has reviewed all his reports on the various schools and Lejac Residential School would appear to be the only other school where there is a special danger by fire. I think, however, that in the case of the Lejac School we will let the matter stand, unless the matter of an allowance is raised by the Principal.

Mr. J.S. Dunn,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Cranbrook, B.C.

We recently received a request from Rev. G.F. Kelly, O.M.I., Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, for an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman. In connection with the request, I may say that the Deputy Minister has ruled as follows:

(1) Allowance for a night watchman must not be paid to a present member of the staff.

(2) Allowance must be paid only to schools which are certified by an engineer as subject to special danger by fire.

We wrote to Indian Commissioner Arneil and he has recommended that we make an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman, due to the fact that one of the Departmental engineers recently reported that there is a fire hazard at the Kootenay School. We presume from the contents of Father Kelly's letter that the man employed is not one of the regular members of the staff.

In view of the above, it has been decided to allow $60.00 a month towards the salary of a night watchman at the Kootenay School for the period 1st January to 30th April, 1949. For your information I may say that at schools where an allowance is made...
towards the salary of a night watchman, it is our usual practice to make this payment from 1st October to the following 30th April. However, as Father Kelly's letter stated that the night watchman only commenced duties on 1st January, 1949, we are only making allowance for four months.

Before the next heating season commences if you consider conditions warrant such assistance, you should apply in September for an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman for the period 1st October, 1949, to 30th April, 1950.

For your guidance I enclose a sample of the Voucher which should be forwarded.

PP/ST Attach.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

MEMORANDUM

Re: Kootenay, Alert Bay and Sechelt Indian Residential Schools, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of February 24th, you are advised that we have had a discussion with officials of the Indian Affairs Branch in connection with proposed inspections of the above schools.

It was pointed out to the Indian Affairs officers, that our program of work includes commitments not only on Indian Affairs work, but Northwest Territories, and National Parks Service projects as well, which will require the services of our heating engineer here in the office, until such time as these items are well along the way to complete development.

It is difficult at this time to state when our officer can be assigned to carry out the mechanical inspections requested for British Columbia, but we will endeavour to arrange our program of work so that these inspections can be made at as early a date as possible.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

Re: Kootenay, Alert Bay and Sechelt Indian Residential Schools, British Columbia

With reference to the above, the Lands & Development Services Branch have written to us as follows under cover of memorandum dated 21st March, 1949:

Also, kindly note that it will be necessary for your Department to obtain permission from the Department of Transport for this use of their substation.

Our ability to carry out this construction will depend on the delivery of material and on the prior requirements of our normal maintenance program.
We have also to advise that at the present time this offer to supply must of necessity be on an if, as and when power is available basis.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: St. Joseph Creek Pipe Line, Kootenay Indian Residential School

A report on the above project has been received from Mr. Mitchell under date of May 23rd, 1949, and we are advised that Mr. Snelson drove from Banff to this school on May 4th to inspect and adjust the hypo-chlorinator for correct operation.

Mr. Snelson found that inadvertently steam had been turned through the water meter. This ruined the hard rubber measuring disc of the meter so the adjustment and regulation of the hypo-chlorinator will have to be postponed until a new disc has been received from the Hypo-chlorinator manufacturers.

Mr. Snelson reports that all works in connection with this project have been completed satisfactorily, including drilling holes and placing 4" pipes through walls, installing injector feed to boiler and all piping in connection with the hypo-chlorinator.

The Indian Agent and the school authorities should be cautioned with regard to the use of raw water from St. Joseph's Creek. Care is especially necessary with regard to the use of water from the two outside standpipes where raw water is used for irrigation. This water from St. Joseph's Creek is contaminated.

Mr. Philip Phalen, Chief,
Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

I am in receipt of two letters from you in the past week for which I wish to thank you very much. One informing me of the cheque as advance payment on the Quarter, which I subsequently received, and the second regarding the Roneo Duplicator. It has not yet arrived but when it does I will write you as requested. I was very pleased to hear that it was coming.

I am wondering if you can do anything to accelerate matters regarding our electric power. We have it within forty feet of the building but seem to have run into a stalemate from there on. With it so close it seems a shame to pass another winter with the present unsatisfactory plant.

Here are the details. In June we were informed that an Order in Council had granted ten thousand dollars for the construction of a power line from the East Kootenay Power Co's substation to the residential school. Following that we were asked by Commissioner Arneil to obtain two estimates by local firms regarding the work to be done in the school building. After these had been sent to Ottawa a letter was received by our Superintendent, Mr. J.S. Dunn, that an electrical engineer would be sent here from the Lands and Development Branch to inspect the school and pass on what was needed. He was to arrive here in July. To date we have not seen him nor have we any information as to what office he was to come from.

When the Power Company got the building of the line under way, Supt. Dunn again wrote requesting that the engineer come so that this work could be completed before winter. When the line was completed two weeks ago I contacted Commissioner Arneil by telephone to enquire what was to be done about the school. He said he had just written Mr. Neary about it and would follow it up from there. However we are still waiting for the desired electrical engineer. While we are very pleased to see the line built and the power so close we are most anxious to get it attached to the school so that we can have its benefit for the winter months.

If you can find out where the delay is and do anything to bring those responsible for it to see the inconvenience being caused we would be very grateful.

Assuring you of our continued cooperation in all matters, I remain,

Sincerely Yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.

Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phalen,

On November 3rd last, Mr. Kosnar, an electrical engineer, from the Ottawa office of Lands and Development, was here to make a survey of our school with a view to installing A.C. Current. He said he would have to recommend many changes in the present wiring and lighting arrangement. He promised to get the matter through as speedily as possible on his return to Ottawa. It is now two months since his survey and we have had no further word on developments. We are in the predicament of having adequate power forty feet from the building and still we are continuing on with this antiquated system. Would you be kind enough to trace up this matter and find out where the delay is. He told me not to expect any action for a month due to the various depts. through which his recommendations would have to pass. But since two months have now passed I fear that this matter has been ditched into somebody's file until next year. I would appreciate it very much if you could find out how soon we can expect action on this matter which grows more urgent every day and which we would like very much to have cleared up.

Sincerely Yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.
MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, British Columbia.

Following a report submitted by the Donald Inspection Company at the above, in which they recommended that the existing lighting in all buildings be improved, Major MacKay indicated in his memorandum to you dated the 4th of December, 1945, that an inspection would probably be necessary in view of the fact that they were contemplating servicing the building with hydro power and a complete change in the wiring system would be required.

Our memorandum to you dated the 21st of May last, pointed out that the inspection would be carried out during a western inspection trip to be made in the fall in British Columbia. The inspection has been made and following is our report and recommendations for work which we consider should be carried out.

The present power supply consists of a 10 K.W. 110 volt direct current diesel electric generating unit which is located adjacent to the boiler room in the Residential School basement. Last year the Indian Affairs Branch entered into an agreement with the East Kootenay Power Company for the construction of approximately 36 miles of 3 phase primary distribution lines from the Wapiti substation. The line has been completed and transformers installed on a pole at the rear of the school for the provision of single phase 115/230 volt and 3 phase 230 volt 3 phase 60 cycle power supply. The reason for the inspection was to determine what work was necessary not only to convert the present electrical system so that it would be capable of receiving this new type of energy, but also to determine if any additional work is necessary.

The buildings located at the site consist of the following in addition to the Residential School Buildings— Barn, Manual Training Building, Dairy, Hen Houses and Forge Building. The barn is at present wired but is in poor condition and it will be necessary to have this building re-wired. The out buildings, with the exception of the ones have no electrical service and it is our opinion that this work should be undertaken at the same time the changes and alterations are being carried out in the Residential School. The percentage of total cost of all the electrical work at the site chargeable to the out buildings, would be small, probably in the order of 20%.

The wiring in the Residential School was installed in concealed rigid steel conduit at the time of construction in 1911. The lighting however, is very poor throughout, especially in areas such as classrooms and the sewing room where the seeing tasks are at a high level. It will be necessary to re-design the lighting by providing additional outlets and fixtures to...
bring it up to present day standards. In this building, as in the majority of buildings wired in the same time period, there are no plug receptacles provided in the original layout for portable equipment. As a result of the lack of sufficient lighting and plug receptacle outlets, considerable extensions have been made, many in a very amateurish manner, and it will be necessary to make alterations and additions to provide a reliable electrical system throughout the school.

Ironing facilities are very inadequate in that all ironing is done by hand by heating flat irons on the sides of a tapered vertical wood burning stove. This is a dangerous practice as the stove is left unattended during heating periods and presents a definite fire hazard. Apart from the danger of fire, the floor space necessary for the stove and wood fuel storage makes very inefficient use of the room in which this equipment is housed, and in our opinion a steam mangle for the larger pieces of laundry together with sufficient electric hand irons, should be provided.

In discussing the laundry operations with the Principal, our officer was informed that great difficulty was experienced with drying facilities. The school is equipped with a heated drying enclosure in which the laundry is hung from removable racks. The difficulty here is undoubtedly due to the lack of air circulation and we are of the opinion that an exhaust fan installation would provide the necessary circulation and removal of damp air from the enclosure, thus eliminating the present practice of removing the heated moisture laden laundry for drying in other areas.

The present direct current motors on the water system and laundry equipment will require replacing by alternating current motors.

The distribution system throughout the school will have to be changed from 2 wire 110 volts to 3 wire 115/230 volts and it is contemplated that the majority of existing conduit runs can be re-used, using thermo-plastic insulated conductors of the required capacities.

The fire escapes at the school, in our opinion, do not offer sufficient facilities for easy removal of the children in case of fire, especially from the dormitories that have recently been built in the attic space. The Indian Affairs Branch is aware of this situation; reference Major MacKay's memorandum dated the 15th of December with correspondence attached thereto and our reply of the 22nd ultimo.

Summarizing the foregoing, we recommend that the Indian Affairs Branch undertake the following work at the school in addition to revising the electrical distribution system to receive the East Kootenay Power supply.

1. Improve the existing lighting to bring it up to modern standards.
2. Wire the existing out-buildings.
3. Improve the ironing facilities by the provision of a steam mangle and electric hand irons.
4. Provide an exhaust fan for the laundry drier.
5. Make alterations and additions to the present fire escapes.

Drawings are in the process of preparation for the changeover to the new electrical service and an early reply regarding the above recommendations will enable us to complete our plans and specifications in the near future. Our proposal in connection with the fire escapes will be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch upon completion.

Chief.

Dear Mr. Arneil: Re; Fire Escapes on Above Building

Further to our telephone conversation of this morning I would like to add a few lines to clarify my suggestions regarding fire escapes.

Mr. J. McCormack of Blair Iron Works, Vancouver, arrived here yesterday bearing blue-prints of the school with instructions to take measurements for new fire-escapes. On looking at the plans I found certain things which I did not think quite advisable and so with all due respect to the engineer who drew them up I would offer these suggestions.

1. Re: The Rear Elevation. As you will see by the plans two escapes come from the third floor to a common landing and thence to the ground. This means that girls in one dormitory can go down the fire escape to the landing and up to the boys dormitory and vice versa. As this would be on the back of the building away from the Prefects it would be a very convenient passage. While at present we are free of any such trouble we don't want to set up an arrangement which would be so convenient. It may be suggested that an electric bell with a switch in the jam of the door leading into the fire escapes, which would operate when the door is opened, would remedy any possible danger. Anyone who has attended boarding school and who wanted to go out to a show knows that a pen knife inserted in the door-jam will silence the bell. Moreover the arrangement as suggested on the plan calls for the removal of a balcony from the rear of the school to be replaced by the fire escape landing. Whoever drew up the plan probably thinks this balcony is useless but to us it has its importance. It adjoins the Sister's living room and as we have screened in this balcony it is a very convenient place for the Sisters. The Sisters use it and would be very sorry to lose it. It would be replaced by a landing it is true but this landing would have no roof over it and could not be screened in so would be unsatisfactory for any other purpose except escaping from fire.

For these reasons I find the plan as outlined by Mr. McCormack quite unsatisfactory. I have suggested to him how the job can be done and the protection made adequate without removing the balcony or giving a free passage from one dormitory to the
other. When this building was constructed individual fire escapes were on the back of this building but subsequently they were removed to the ends. We have followed quite closely the original course which these took.

II) The End Elevation. Four windows are shown on the end elevation. The two nearer the centre of the building have been chosen as exits for the fire escape. I would suggest using the two nearer the corners. From the outside it looks as though either are feasible however on the inside there is a difference. The two windows nearer the centre have a heating coil more than half way across them. For the present sash which raise up and down this is satisfactory but the new plan calls for windows opening in and these heating coils rise four inches above the bottom of the sash. Therefore in order to operate windows opening in these heating coils will have to be removed. This entails changing the feed lines which come from the basement. Moreover the heating coils are properly placed where they now are and it will be difficult to find another place where they will be suitable. The expense of moving them would be considerable. Whereas if the windows nearer the corners of the building be used as exits there are no obstructions in front of them. By using them a more gentle slope would be maintained on the fire escape stairs as the distance from these windows to the centre platform as outlined in the drawing is greater. I am enclosing confirmation of my Army Signals message of today's date requesting that the submission to Council for acceptance of Blair Iron Works' tender for installation of fire escapes, Kootenay Residential School, be withheld.

The attached letter dated March 24th from the Reverend Principal of the school indicates why this action was requested. You will note that he objects to the installation of the structures as shown on the plan on the rear elevation of the building for two reasons:

(1) The common fire escape landing from the girls' and boys' dormitories permits of access from one dormitory to another so readily that there is bound to be difficulty with the boys entering the girls' dormitory and vice versa.

I am of the opinion that Father Kelly's fears in this respect are well founded.

(2) The installation as shown on the plan necessitates the removal of a balcony which has been screened for the use of the Sisters whose accommodation is already too confined, without losing this access to the fresh air.

Father Kelly also objects to the installation as shown on the plan of the end elevation, but the difficulties he
suggests will be encountered can be easily overcome, and it is considered that the fire escapes on the end elevation should be proceeded with as planned.

To revert to the fire escape on the rear elevation, we have gone into this matter thoroughly with our engineering staff and Mr. Blair of the Blair Iron Works, and on the attached plan have indicated two proposals, No. 1 of which will obviate access from the boys' dormitory to the girls' dormitory, but still necessitates the removal of the balcony, and No. 2, which will obviate both the disadvantages mentioned by Father Kelly. Of these two proposals we of course favour No. 2 as shown in yellow on the plan on which Blair Iron Works reference their letter of March 28th, quoted a price of $7,923.52. On the alternative proposal as shown in red on the plan, the Company quotes a price of $6,636.52.

Having in mind that these escapes are permanent installations and that the school will likely be in use for years to come I would strongly recommend approval of Proposal No. 2 and acceptance of Blair Iron Works tender of $7,923.52. I might add that the Blair Iron Works are proceeding with the accepted contract by making the fire escapes for the ends of the building but will defer any work on the fire escapes under question pending further advice.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Fire Escapes - Kootenay Residential School,
Cranbrook, British Columbia.

With reference to our memorandum of the 27th March, the application to Council on behalf of the Indian Affairs Branch has been withdrawn pending review of a letter from the Reverend Father G.F. Kelly, O.M.I., Principal of the school which was forwarded with comment by Commissioner Arneil in a covering letter dated the 29th March.

In explanation, the rear metal stair fire escapes were located by this Service to provide outside exits from the attic dormitories so that the passage of pupils in case of fire could reach the ground in the most expeditious manner and at the same time reduce the cost of installation to a minimum.

It appears that our design showing a landing located on a lower storey of the fire escapes for common use from both the boys and girls dormitories, causes concern to Father Kelly, inasmuch as it forms a convenient form of communication between the two dormitories, unless the exit doors were kept locked, and it must be admitted that Father Kelly's suggestion that fire escapes be separate, is worth consideration.

Also our plan called for the removal of a wooden balcony to facilitate erection of the fire escapes. In respect to this balcony, Father Kelly's letter concludes by saying, "whatever decision may be made, please save the balcony. The accommodation of the Sisters is confined enough without removing this access to fresh air."

Commissioner Arneil concurs in Father Kelly's suggestions and under the circumstances, it is felt that separate fire escapes giving exits from each of the dormitories and leaving the balcony for the Sisters, should be given consideration by Indian Affairs.

The original estimate of cost for fire escapes of $5,992.79 from the Blair Iron Works which was approved, will be increased to $7,923.52 if the Principal's recommendation is accepted.

In view of Father Kelly's concern, it is felt that the balcony may be left intact and that separate fire escapes for the boys and girls dormitories be erected at the revised lump sum price of $7,923.52.

Should this proposal meet with the approval of Indian Affairs, a revised memorandum to Council will be implemented immediately.

Chief.

Assignments

5. The Contractor shall not assign or sublet this contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained: Provided, however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such works, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any sub-contractor; and the Contractor shall be held entirely and alone responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work contracted for.

Contractor to investigate every condition of work before execution of contract

6. This contract is made and entered into by the Contractor and His Majesty on the distinct understanding that the Contractor has, before execution investigated and satisfied himself of everything and of every condition affecting the works to be executed and the labour and material to be provided, and that the execution of this contract by the Contractor is founded and based upon his own examination, knowledge, information and judgment, and not upon any statement, representation, or information made or given by, or upon any information derived from any quantities, dimensions, tests, specifications, plans, maps or profiles made, given or furnished by His Majesty or any of His officers, employees or agents; and that any such statements, representation or information, as so made, given or furnished, was made, given or furnished merely for the general information of bidders and is not in anywise warranted or guaranteed by or on behalf of His Majesty; and that no extra allowance will be made to the Contractor by, and the Contractor will make no claim against, His Majesty for any loss or damage sustained in consequence of, or by reason of any such statement, representation or information being incorrect or inaccurate, or on account of unforeseen difficulties of any kind.

Construction of Contract

7. The several parts of this contract and the specifications and plans shall be taken together to explain each other and to make the whole consistent; and if it is found that anything has been omitted or mis-stated which is necessary for the proper performance or completion of any part of the work the Contractor shall, at his own expense, execute the same as though it had been inserted and properly described, and the correction of any such omission or error shall not be deemed to be an addition to or deviation from the works hereby contracted for.
Changes in Work

8. The Engineer may, in writing, at any time before the final acceptance of the works, order any additional work, or materials or things to be done or provided, or the whole or any portion of the works to be dispensed with, or any changes to be made which he may deem expedient in, or in respect of the works hereby contracted for, or the plans, dimensions, character, quantity, quality, description, location or position of the works, or any portion or portions thereof, or in any materials or things connected therewith, or used or intended to be used therein, whether or not the effect of such orders is to increase or diminish the work to be done or the materials or things to be provided or the cost of doing or providing the same; and the Engineer may, in such order or from time to time as he may see fit, specify the time or times within which each order shall, in whole or in part, be complied with. The Contractor shall comply with every such order of the Engineer. The decision of the Engineer as to whether the compliance with such order increases or diminishes the work to be done, or the materials or things to be provided, or the cost of doing or providing the same, and as to the amount to be paid or deducted, as the case may be, in respect thereof, shall be final. As a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to payment in respect of any such order of the Engineer, the Contractor shall obtain and produce the order, in writing, of the Engineer, and a certificate, in writing, of the Engineer, showing compliance with such order and fixing the amount to be paid or deducted in respect thereof.

Consent herein applies to extra work

9. All the clauses of this contract shall apply to any changes, additions, deviations, or additional work, so ordered by the Engineer, in like manner and to the same extent as to the works contracted for.

No claim for anticipated profits

10. If any change or deviation in or omission from the works be made by which the amount of work to be done shall be decreased, or if the whole or any portion of the works be dispensed with, no compensation shall be claimable by the Contractor for any loss of anticipated profits in respect thereof.

Descriptions of work; what items include

11. The description, or descriptions of the work and materials or any portion or portions of the works, set out or referred to in or covered by any item or items for which a price or prices are given in this contract, include not only the particular kinds of materials mentioned in the said item or items, but also all and every kind of work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever necessary for the full execution, completion and delivery, ready for use, of such respective portions of the works in accordance with the plans, drawings and specifications, to the satisfaction of the Engineer. The said price or prices shall cover not only the particular description of work and materials mentioned herein or shown on the plans, but also all and every kind of work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever necessary for the full execution, completion and delivery, ready for use, of the entire work as herein contracted for to the satisfaction of the Engineer. In case of dispute as to what work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things are so included or covered, the decision of the Engineer shall be final and conclusive with respect thereto.
Temporary Buildings and Office

12. The Contractor shall erect and maintain at his own expense, any temporary buildings that may be required for the work, or workmen, and shall provide an office for the use of the Engineer.

The location of all buildings, plant and equipment must be approved by the Engineer before any erection work is begun.

Execution of work directed by Engineer

13. The work shall be commenced, carried on and prosecuted to completion by the Contractor in all its several parts in such manner and at such points and places as the Engineer shall from time to time, direct, and to his satisfaction, but always according to the provisions of this contract, and if no direction is given by the Engineer, then in a careful, prompt and workmanlike manner.

Work subject to control of Engineer

14. The work shall in every particular be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Engineer; and all orders, directions or instructions at any time given by the Engineer with respect thereto, or concerning the conduct thereof, shall by the Contractor promptly and efficiently be obeyed, performed and complied with to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Engineer's stakes or other marks not to be removed

15. The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes buoys or other marks placed on or about the said works by the Engineer or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

Orders for Engineer's Agent

16. All orders, directions, instructions or notices to be given or issued by the Engineer, under and pursuant to any section in this contract, may be given or issued by a duly and expressly authorized agent or agents of the Engineer.

Notice: how given

17. Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman, addressed to the address mentioned in this contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence. Every such notice, order, direction or communication shall be sufficient when expressed in general language and without detail the matters required or communicated, or which follows the general language of the section or sections of this contract under which it is given, and no objection shall be taken to the form thereof.

Foreman of the works

18. A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during all the working hours, to receive the orders of the Engineer. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor, and shall have full power to carry out all requisitions and instructions of the said Engineer, but this clause shall not relieve the Contractor from the duty of personally superintending the work.
Engineer sole judge of work and material

19. The Engineer shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of this contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specification shall be final, and no work under this contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Engineer is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor.

Quality

20. The works shall be constructed by the Contractor and under his personal supervision, of new materials throughout; the best materials of their several kinds, and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in the manner required by and in strict conformity with this contract, the said specifications and special plans and specifications, and the plans and drawings relating thereto, and the working or detail drawings which may from time to time be furnished, which said specifications and special plans and drawings are hereby declared to be part of this contract.

Defective work or material

21. Should the Contractor use or employ, or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools, equipment, articles or things which, in the opinion of the Engineer are not in accordance with the provisions of this contract or are in any way unsuitable for the works or any part thereof, or should the Engineer consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively or insufficiently executed or performed the Engineer may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things, or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders; and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours, the Engineer may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed, the orders so given and the Contractor shall, on demand, pay to His Majesty all costs, damages and expenses incurred in respect thereof, or occasioned to His Majesty by reason of the non-compliance by the Contractor with any such orders, or His Majesty may, in the discretion of the Minister, retain and deduct such costs, damages and expenses from any amounts then or thereafter payable to the Contractor.

Insufficient workmen, plant, etc.

22. If the Engineer shall at any time consider the number of workmen, horses, quantity of machinery, tools, plant or equipment, or of proper materials articles or things, respectively, employed or provided by the Contractor on or for the said works to be insufficient for the advancement of such works or any part thereof towards completion within the time limited in respect thereof, or that the works or some parts thereof, are not being carried on with due diligence, then, and in every such case, the Engineer may, in writing, order the Contractor to employ, or provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may think necessary, and in case the Contractor shall fail within three days, or such other longer period as may be fixed by any such order, in all respects comply therewith, the Engineer may employ and provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, as he may think proper, and
may pay such additional workmen such wages, and for such additional horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, any such prices as he may think proper and all such amounts so paid shall, on demand, be repaid to His Majesty by the Contractor, or the same may be retained or deducted from any sum that may thereafter be or become due from His Majesty to the Contractor. The Contractor shall employ the additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things so provided and employed by the Engineer in the diligent advancement of the works; the workmen and horses so provided shall, however, be thereafter subject to discharge by the Contractor, but only with the consent and approval of the Engineer.

Contractor's machinery, plant, etc.

23. All machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever provided by the Contractor or by the Engineer under the provisions of sections 21 and 22 for the works, and not rejected under the provisions of section 21 shall from the time of their being so provided, become and until the final completion of the said work, shall be the property of His Majesty for the purpose of the said works, and the same shall on no account be taken away, or used or disposed of, except for the purposes of the said works, without the consent in writing of the Engineer. His Majesty shall not, however, be answerable for any loss or damage whatsoever which may at any time happen to such machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles or things. Upon the completion of the works and upon payment by the Contractor of all such money lost, cost and damages, if any, as shall be due from the Contractor to His Majesty, or chargeable against the Contractor under this contract, such of the said machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things as shall not have been used and converted in the works or disposed of by His Majesty under powers conferred in this contract, shall, upon demand, be delivered up to the Contractor in such condition as they may then be in.

Work not comprised in contract

24. His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the works other contractors and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in this contract, and the Contractor shall afford to them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Engineer may deem practical.

The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the works of the Contractor for such purposes shall not be deemed an acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the works comprised in this contract.

Co-operation with other Contractors

25. That whenever and so often as it may be necessary for the Contractor to co-operate with other contractors on this work, or any or either of them, the Contractor shall diligently and under the directions of the Engineer perform all such works as shall be requisite and proper on the part of the Contractor herein for such co-operation and for securing and placing in proper position the portion necessary herein and hereby contracted to be constructed and erected for the proposed work in a proper and secure hold, and to prevent the possibility of any accident therefrom without any extra charge therefor, and shall be bound in all things to conform to the direction of the Minister or the Engineer touching such cooperation and work.
Defect or delay by Contractor

26. In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the works or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under this contract, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, the Engineer may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Engineer to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in the completion of the works, or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent, or abandon the work, or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required, or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of this contract, then and in any of such cases the Minister, for and behalf of His Majesty, and with at any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he, on His Majesty's behalf, may see fit to complete the works, and in such case the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment in respect of work performed, but shall be responsible with and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the works, and no objection or claim shall be raised or made by the Contractor by reason or on account of the ultimate cost of the work so taken over, for any reason proving greater than in the opinion of the Contractor it should have been; and all materials, articles and things whatsoever, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights, proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Engineer under the provisions of this contract shall remain and be the property of His Majesty for all purposes incidental to the completion of the works, and may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty as fully to all intents and purposes connected with the works as they might therefore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor; and the Minister may, in his option, on behalf of His Majesty, sell or otherwise dispose of, at forced sale prices, or at public auction or private sale or otherwise, the whole or any portion or number of such materials, articles, things, horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment at such price or prices as he may see fit, and detain the proceeds of any such sale or disposition and all other amounts then or thereafter due by His Majesty to the Contractor on account of, or in part satisfaction of any loss or damage which His Majesty may sustain or have sustained by reason aforesaid.

Power to take action on default of Contractor

27. Whenever in this contract power or authority is given to His Majesty, the Minister, the Engineer, or any person on behalf of His Majesty, to take any action consequent upon the insolvency of the Contractor, or upon the acts, defaults, neglects, delays, breaches, non-observance or non-performance by the Contractor in respect of the works or any portion or details thereof, such power or authorities may be exercised from time to time, and not only in the event of the happening of such contingencies before the time limited in this contract for the completion of the works but also in the event of the same happening after the time so limited in the case of the Contractor being permitted to further proceed with the execution of the works.
Delays

28. The Contractor shall not have nor make any claim or demand, nor bring any action or suit or petition against His Majesty for any damage which he may sustain by reason of any delay or delays from whatever cause arising in the progress of the work.

No Implied Contracts

29. It is distinctly declared that no implied contract of any kind whatsoever by or on behalf of His Majesty shall arise or be implied from anything, in the contract documents contained or from any position or situation of the parties at any time, it being clearly understood and agreed that the express contract covenants and agreements therein contained and made by His Majesty are and shall be the only contracts, covenants and agreements upon which any rights against His Majesty are founded.

Parliamentary appropriations exhausted

30. Should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment for the work hereby contracted for be at any time expended previous to the completion of the works, the Minister or the Engineer may give the Contractor written notice to that effect. Upon receiving such notice the Contractor may, if he thinks fit, stop the work but shall not be entitled to any payment for work done beyond the amount voted and applicable as aforesaid, until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf. And in no event shall the Contractor have or make any claim on His Majesty for any damages or compensation by reason of the suspension of payment, or by reason of any delay or loss caused by the stoppage of the work. And in the event of the Contractor electing to proceed, or proceeding with such work after such notice, and before such additional funds are voted, no action of the Engineer, or of any other person on behalf of His Majesty, in giving orders, instructions or directions, or otherwise acting with respect to such work, shall be taken or considered as in any manner improving the rights of the Contractor or as waiving in any particular any of the provisions of this section.

Minister may suspend work

31. The Minister may, from time to time and for such period as he may deem expedient, delay or suspend, in whole or in part, operations under this contract, either upon the whole of the works, or at any particular point or points. Should any such delay or suspension, or the stoppage of the works under the provisions of Section 30, or should any delay caused by any circumstance which, in the opinion of the Engineer, is beyond the control of or not the fault of the Contractor, in the opinion of the Minister unreasonably limit the time for the completion of the works, within the time specified by this contract, the Minister so often as the case occurs shall allow such additional time as to him may seem sufficient in the extension of such time for completion; but no such delay, suspension or stoppage shall vitiate or avoid this contract, or any part thereof, or any security or obligations for the performance thereof, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to make any claim for damages by reason thereof. Upon the termination of such delay, suspension or stoppage, or upon the removal of the cause thereof, or upon the Contractor receiving notice from the Minister or Engineer requiring him to resume the work, he shall at once resume operations and diligently carry on the same.
32. No condoning, excusing or overlooking by His Majesty, or any person acting on his behalf, on previous occasions, or breaches or defaults similar to that for which any action is taken or power exercised, or forfeiture is claimed or enforced against the Contractor, shall be taken to operate as a waiver of any provision of this contract, nor to defeat or prejudice in any way the right of His Majesty thereunder.

Members of H. of C. not to benefit

33. Pursuant to the provision of the Statute in such case made and provided, no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

No Public Ceremony

34. The Contractor shall not allow any public ceremony in connection with the work without having previously obtained the written permission of the Minister.

Liquors

35. The Contractor shall not bring nor permit to be brought anywhere on or, as far as the Contractor can prevent the same, near the works any spirituous or intoxicating liquor; and if any person employed on the works be, in the opinion of the Engineer, intemperate, disorderly, incompetent, wilfully negligent, or dishonest in the performance of his duties, he shall, on the direction of the Engineer, be forthwith discharged and the Contractor shall not employ or permit to remain on the work any person who shall have been discharged for any or all of said causes.

Sanitation

36. The Contractor shall comply with, and the works shall be carried on subject to, all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said works, and all orders given by the Engineer with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the works. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, provide suitable privies and make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

Contractor to clean premises on completion

37. The Contractor shall upon the completion of the works, remove all temporary structures and clear away all rubbish and surplus and waste materials remaining on or about the works, and place the premises in a neat and tidy condition, satisfactory to the Engineer.

Damages to persons or property

38. The Contractor, his agents and all workmen and persons employed by him, or under his control, shall use due care that no person or property is injured and that no rights are infringed in the prosecution of the work, and the Contractor shall be solely responsible for all damages, by whomsoever claimed, in respect of any injury to persons or to lands, buildings, structures, fences, trees, crops, roads, ways, ships, or property of whatever description, and in respect of any infringement of any right, privilege or easement whatsoever occasioned in the carrying on of the works or any part thereof, or by any neglect, misfeasance or nonfeasance on the Contractor's part or on the part of any of his agents,

workmen or persons employed by him or under his control, and shall at his own expense, make such temporary provisions as may be necessary to ensure the avoidance of any such damage, injury or infringement, and to prevent the interruption of or danger or menace to the traffic on any public or private road, and to secure to all persons and corporations the uninterrupted enjoyment of all their rights in and during the performance of the said works; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by or attributable to any such damage, injury or infringement.

Damages to work in progress. Contractor assumes risk

39. The Contractor shall be at the risk of, and shall bear all loss or damage whatsoever, from whatsoever cause arising, which may occur to the work, or any part thereof, until the same be finally accepted by the Minister, and if any such loss or damage occur before such final acceptance, the Contractor shall immediately, at his own expense, repair, restore and re-execute the work so damaged, so that the whole works, or their respective portions thereof, shall be completed within the time limited for completion thereof, and any delay occasioned by the Contractor to the other contractors on the work or any interference by the Contractor with the operations which may be a cause of delay or damage shall be rectified at the cost of, and the claim for damage or delay (if any) shall be at the charge of the Contractor.

Precautions as to fire

40. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the works and employ his own workmen, to the satisfaction and under the direction of the Engineer, in extinguishing all such fires which may occur; and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given, from time to time during construction, by the Engineer with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires, and shall pay all wages and other outlay occasioned by reason of the observance or compliance with such regulations and instructions.

Fire Insurance

41. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, at all times during construction and until the final acceptance of the work, keep all buildings and structures insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts equal to at least Eighty (80) per cent of the value of work done and materials accepted by the Engineer, as may be approved by the Chief, and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty may respectively appear, and shall be deposited with the Chief.

Protection of Workmen

42. The Contractor shall protect the Department from all claims that may arise from injury to, or sickness of, any workmen employed by him on the work.
Workmen's Compensation

43. The Contractor will be required to comply with the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Act for the province in which the work is being carried on.

Payment by Contractor for Labour, etc.

44. The Contractor shall promptly pay for all labour, service and materials in or about the construction of the works, and all payments for such purposes shall be made by the Contractor, at least as often as payments are made to the Contractor by His Majesty under this contract, and in the event of failure by the Contractor at any time so to do, or if any sum due for labour of any foreman or workman, or for hire of horses, teams or carts upon or in respect of the works or any part thereof, remains in arrears or unpaid, or if there be at any time found to exist any claims against the Contractor, or any sub-contractor, for labour, teams, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles or things employed, hired or supplied upon or for the works or any part thereof, or if the Minister has reason to believe that any such payments, sums or claims will not be promptly made or paid, the Minister may, in addition to, or in lieu of exercising any powers conferred by the Labour Conditions, at his option, retain out of any moneys due or become due to the Contractor from His Majesty such amount or amounts as the Minister may deem sufficient to satisfy the same, or pay the Contractor the moneys due him in instalments, giving him from time to time such sums as the Minister or the Engineer deems sufficient to meet such payments, sums or claims, any of them, and withholding the balance due him after deducting the payments so made. The Contractor shall be estopped from denying the accuracy and correctness of any and all payments so made by the Minister.

Books, etc., of Contractor open for inspection

45. The Contractor's pay-rolls, time-books, books of account, invoices and statements shall be at all times open for inspection and extract by the Engineer and any authorized representative of the Minister, or either of them who shall be assisted in every possible way by the Contractor, to enable the Engineer and such representative to ascertain, as far as possible, the exact payment, sums or claims so due and remaining unpaid by the Contractor.

Work to be free from all encumbrances

46. Before making any payment on any progress estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to satisfy the Engineer or other authorized representative of His Majesty, that all work performed and materials supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kind of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished, or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

Statutory Declaration

47. Upon completion of the work, and before payment is made on any final estimate, certificate, or statement the Contractor shall submit to the Engineer, a statement attested by Statutory Declaration showing that all works performed and materials supplied are free of all lawful liens or claims.
Proofs required for default of Contractor

48. The Minister or the Engineer may, in their discretion, at any time require proof, with such formalities or to such extent as they may deem requisite, of any claim under the said Fair Wage Clauses or Schedules, or for wages or hire of teams in arrears or of accounts for materials, or other things unpaid.

Schedule of Unit Prices

49. The Contractor shall submit with his tender a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis of payments for all work under the contract.

Classification of Costs

50. There shall also be submitted at the same time, a classification of costs at the schedule of unit prices submitted, aggregating the total contract price. This schedule shall be so computed that all incidental charges shall be distributed over the various trade items as shown on the Departmental Progress Estimate form or as approved by the Chief Engineer, and shall be used as a basis for the Engineer's Monthly Progress Estimates.

Prices to be accepted as full compensation

51. The said price or prices shall be accepted by the Contractor as full compensation for everything furnished and done by the Contractor under this contract, including all work required but not included in the items hereinabove mentioned, and also for all loss or damage arising out of the nature of the works or the action of the weather, tides, elements, or any unforeseen obstruction or difficulty encountered in the prosecution of the work, and for all risks of every description connected with the works, and for all expenses incurred by or in connection with the works, and for all works, and for all expenses incurred by or in consequence of any delay or suspension or discontinuance of the work as herein specified, and for well and faithfully completing the works as in this contract provided.

Progress payments

52. Payments equal to about ninety per cent of the value of the work done, approximately estimated from progress measurements and computed at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, will be made to the Contractor monthly if practicable, on the written certificate of the Engineer, stating that the work for or on account of which the certificate is granted has been done, and stating the value of work computed as above mentioned; and the said certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid the said ninety per cent or any part thereof. The remaining ten per cent shall be retained till the final completion of the whole work to the satisfaction of the Engineer, and will be paid within two months after such completion. The written certificate of the said Engineer certifying to the final completion of the said works to his satisfaction, shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or to be paid the remaining ten per cent or any part thereof.
Engineer in certifying values for progress payments may disregard price list

53. Provided always that, where in the opinion of the Engineer the work done is not sufficiently finished, or is not of sufficient value to justify payment at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, the Engineer may, for the purpose of such payment, disregard the price or prices agreed upon or determined and may estimate the proportionate value payable in respect of such work and issue a certificate accordingly; in which case the Contractor shall only be entitled to receive ninety per cent of such estimated proportionate value as stated in such certificate, and shall not be paid the ninety per cent of the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, until such time as the Engineer, by reason of the performance of additional work, shall certify that the Contractor is entitled thereto.

Claims under progress certificate

54. It is intended that every allowance to which the Contractor is fairly entitled will be embraced in the Engineer's monthly certificate, but should the Contractor at any time have claims of any description which he considers are not included in the progress certificates, such claims must be made in writing to the Engineer within thirty days after the date of the delivery to him of the certificate from which he considers the items of such claims to have been omitted, but in no case beyond the period of sixty days from the date of the practical completion of that portion of the work to which such claims apply. And in default of the presentation of such claims within the times so limited the Minister may treat such claims as absolutely barred.

Claims, evidence of accuracy

55. The Contractor in presenting claims of the kind referred to in the last preceding clause must accompany them with satisfactory evidence of their accuracy and the reason why he thinks they should be allowed.

Payment for additional or extra work

56. Payment for any work or additional work done, or materials or things provided, under the written orders of the Engineer, for which no price or prices are named, and which is not covered by the contract, His Majesty in consideration and subject, as aforesaid, will pay to the Contractor the actual and reasonable cost, as determined by the Engineer of such work, materials and things, with an additional ten per cent thereon for the use of tools, Contractor's plant, superintendence and profits.

Approximate quantities

57. The quantities (if any) given are approximate only and no claim shall be made by the Contractor against His Majesty on account of any excess or deficiency, absolute or relative, in the same.

Progress measurements and certificates not binding

58. Considerable difficulty has been encountered in connection with the above installation, due to the fact that the plans and specifications called for the installation of casement windows opening inward to give access to the fire escape platforms. Apart from the fact that the inward opening of the casements is contrary to fire regulations, their installation in this manner was not possible without extensive changes to the heating system for the reason that the radiators placed in front of the windows projected above the bottom of the proposed casements effectively preventing them from opening.

Father Kelly communicated with us by telephone and explained this difficulty in some detail and, as the contractors, Blair Iron Works, were on the job and completion of the work could not be delayed, we authorized completion of the installation less the installation of the casement windows. Father Kelly has since written us in connection with the matter and a copy of his letter of June 16th is enclosed for your information. You will note in the second paragraph of page two of his letter he suggests two solutions to the difficulty. This office favours the installation of doors as proposed by Father Kelly and, if it is considered necessary, we will have one of our engineers visit the school and report with regard to the work involved and the expense.

In the meantime, Blair Iron Works have submitted their final progress payment, which covers the full amount of the contract less a credit of $67.00 for the casement sash, which were not installed. Dear Mr. Arneil:

It always delights the heart of a Principal to see new installations and improvements around the school. This is particularly true when these tend to a greater measure of safety for the children under his care. I was very pleased when informed that new fire escapes were to be installed here to insure a speedy and safe exit from the building in the event of a fire. However, I didn't expect to find an obstacle included in the plans which would render the exit unnecessarily difficult. I refer to the plan calling for two windows (or doors as they may be called) hinged at the sides, closing in the centre, and opening in. These are prescribed for the six main exits from the dormitories.

When I saw the plans calling for this installation I contacted our Agency Superintendent, Mr. Dunn, who came down here and we discussed the matter together. We suggested leaving the present casements as is and hinging the windows to open out. Our reasons were: the facility of exit when they open out; and to avoid removal of the heating radiators which rise four inches above the window sill and at present would obstruct windows designed to open in. This second reason was evidently not considered by the engineer who drew up the plans and it is quite a serious matter. Not only will it involve a considerable expense, (each radiator is ten feet long and eight inches wide and there are four of them), but also the pipe lines leading to them from the mains in the basement will have to be relocated. This will involve cutting through floors and ceilings from the basement to the second floor.

This morning I was again speaking to Mr. Dunn and he said he had a reply from you to the effect that the work should proceed according to the plans given to the Blair Iron Works. The reason for this is, as I understand it, that if they opened out they would obstruct the landing. Quite true if they are hinged on the outer edge of the casement but the casements are 19" in width and the windows suggested are 22½" in width and if they are hinged on the inner edge of the casement they will only protrude 3½". The landing
platform which is being installed is 3' 3" in width so there would be no obstruction on it. To my mind they present a much more serious hazard opening in than they would by protruding 3½" beyond the edge of the building. As I understand it when and if a fire occurs the responsibility of evacuating the children falls upon the Principal and his staff. I think it is unfair to expect anyone to guarantee the evacuation of children when the exit windows open in. Even if a special permission is granted from the proper authorities for this type of construction it doesn't alter the fact that the actual responsibility at the time of the fire, should such occur, falls on those in immediate charge. Why should plans call for making an exit difficult when it is possible and quite reasonable to make it convenient?

I would like to suggest one of two things. Firstly, if we are bound to follow the plans submitted, then hinge the windows on the inner edge of the present casement. Or, secondly, and I feel this is the answer, hinge one door as shown in the attached sketch, to open out. This door to be provided with a panel window as shown. It will hinge on one side of the casement, the side farthest from the stairs descending, and when opened will swing back to the railing on the back of the landing platform entirely clear of the stairs. When closed it will have a catch on the opposite side of the casement and if recommended can be equipped with a fire-bar. This installation is very simple. The present casements can be left undisturbed. Only the doors of the size required equipped with a glass panel as shown need to be provided.

Moreover, it should be remembered that these exits are being put in places where formerly there were windows equipped with double windows for the winter months. If the suggested windows as called for on the plans given to Blair Iron Works are installed they are ninety-five per cent glass and will give considerable exposure. In the colder months they will be a mass of frost. Some provision will then have to be made for doubling them. This will entail a new problem which the use of a door will eliminate. The dormitories at present during the winter months are not too warm and this added exposure of single windows as suggested by the plans will augment the heating problem. This trouble can be obviated very easily if doors are used with a panel window of reasonable size the exposure of which would be negligible.

I know that all this is hard to follow and visualize from a letter. I am going to Penticton on June 23rd with the children who are returning home for the summer vacation and I would be pleased to continue on to Vancouver and explain the matter in person if you
so advise. I feel quite sure that if you could visit here and see the actual set-up you would agree that an alteration in the plans as given to Blair Iron Works is quite reasonable.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) G.F. Kelly O.M.I. Principal.
