Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 9 May 1950.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 2nd May, 1950, from the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, representing:

That the existing fire exits from the dormitories in the attic storey of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C., are inadequate, and that this condition creates a hazard to the pupils and staff domiciled therein;

That tenders for the supply and erection of exterior metal fire escapes, based on drawings prepared by the Engineering and Construction Service of the Department of Resources and Development, were invited from contractors in the area and that only one contractor, the Blair Iron Works of New Westminster, B.C., was in a position to tender;

That the said Blair Iron Works submitted a quotation offering to carry out the work by contract for the lump sum price of $7,923.52, which price is considered reasonable;

That when allowance is made for unforeseen contingencies, supervision, etc., the total expenditure may amount to approximately $8,500.00;

That the work is considered of an emergent character, and that delay occasioned by a further call for tenders would not be in the public interest;

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, advise that authority be granted to accept the tender of the Blair Iron Works of New Westminster, B.C., for the supply and erection of exterior metal stair fire escapes as above set out, at a total cost not to exceed $8,500.00; the security to be deposited by the contractor to be in the amount of $350.00 only; funds for which are available in Vote 59, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, Estimates 1950-51.

The sight of electricians around here is like manna in the desert. As you know the good news came through a week ago and work is well under way. Mr F.S. Ryckman,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I would be glad if you would request the Department to grant our school two months' holidays, for the months of July and August as has been done for the two preceding years.

The value of this extension has been very evident in former years due to the improvement in the health of the children, and also the educational advantage, as the children return to school all together in September satisfied and willingly.

The climate of the Kootenay district is very hot during the summer months and favors the outdoor camp life enjoyed by the Indians during this season.

Trusting that you will give this matter your favorable attention, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Rev. J.M. Patterson, O.M.I.

Sir:

As pointed out in my letter of August 11, 1931, fyle 11/732, there was formerly a good deal of expense to the Department in having the children brought back to school, and the supplying of gasoline and oil only will effect a considerable saving. I beg to submit that if authority be granted to supply the Indians with gasoline and oil as requested the cost will be kept as low as possible.

Dear Sir:

I wish to request the Department to grant us the two months' vacation this year as has been granted during the last three years.

This extension of holidays has been so beneficial to the Kootenay Indian children that I would like to have it made permanent if it is possible for the Department to do so. We have found that for the last three years the children have returned readily to school without any necessity at all of compulsion as formerly. Also these children for the most part live in their tepees during the vacations, and we find that their health resistance improves considerably. As they are continually moving about there is not the usual danger of tubercular contagion, and freedom from school restraint for two months makes them eager for studies again. During the two months of July and August the weather is very hot in the Kootenays and is not conducive to studies of any kind, for Indian children.

Trusting you will forward this request to the Department at your earliest opportunity, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Rev. J.H. Patterson, O.M.I.

Ottawa, August 11th, 1935.

Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to returning children to the Kootenay Indian Residential School after the summer holidays.

If the Indians of the reserves mentioned in your letter are in a position to own cars, it is considered that they should have sufficient interest in their children's education to return them to the school without cost either to the Department or the school management.

I am aware that you submitted accounts last year to the amount of, approximately, $43.00, for gas and oil supplied Indians returning their children to the Kootenay School. Our funds this year have been considerably reduced and you should endeavour to have the Indians return their children without cost. If, however, you find it absolutely necessary to supply some gas and oil, the Department will be prepared to consider payment of an expenditure not exceeding $25.00.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,

Dear Sir:

I wish to request the Indian Department to grant us the usual summer holidays from July 1st to September 1st, as has been done during the last four years.

We have always credited this extension of holidays as the source of great improvement in the health of our children as well as giving general satisfaction to our Indians. During these two months the weather in the Kootenays is as a rule too hot to carry on satisfactory school work. Our pupils generally spend the summer vacations in their tepees and the majority are well cared for at this time of the year. Many of our children live long distances from the school and spend considerable time travelling to their homes.

I would be glad therefore if the Department will give favorable consideration to this request as they have already done in the past.

Yours faithfully,

Rev. J.M. Patterson, O.M.I.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, it is noted that there are only three children sixteen years of age or over, at present in the Kootenay Indian Residential School. It is noted, also, that you will write, later, with reference to whether you consider they should be discharged or retained in the school.

In writing the circular letter of the 15th instant, it was the Department's intention to bring to the attention of Principals of Indian Residential Schools the necessity for their asking the Department for permission to allow children who are 16 years of age or over to remain for a further period.

In future, requests should be forwarded whenever children reach 16 years of age, and the correspondence should be directed through the Indian Agent's office, in order that he may make any recommendation that he considers necessary.

Headquarters

1. A complaint was made by the Indian Agent, Cranbrook B.C., also by Father Patterson, Principal of the St. Eugene Mission school, St. Mary's Reserve, that the above mentioned boy had run away from school and was, no doubt returning to his home on the Shuswap Indian reserve, so were requested to make every effort to bring this boy back.

Sub-Division Cranbrook
Detachment

2. Acting upon instructions received from the B.C.O.I/C, Cranbrook Detachment, I left Cranbrook per Police Ford car Code No.1072, during the morning of the 26th Inst., on patrol to the Shuswap Indian Reserve. Enquiries were made enroute, and from his father and mother, but with no results. This boy was found in Cranbrook by another Indian, and turned over to the Cranbrook Detachment, during the late P.M. of the 26th Inst.

3. SYLVESTER was immediately returned to the Indian Mission school.

Ottawa, July 10, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing the June quarter return of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, together with applications for the admission of two pupils and the discharge of four.

The admission of Luke Alban and Bertha Alban is approved.

Regarding Bertha Alban, it is noted that she has congenital dislocation of the left hip and also eczema. The Principal and medical officer of the school should see that this girl receives the attention her case may require.

The discharge of the following pupils is approved:

No. 161 - Thomas Whitehead
No. 225 - Andrew Basil
No. 224 - Sam Nicholas.

Please advise the Principal accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

F. S. Ryckman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Granbrook, B.C.

Fyle References Re: Mary & Elizabeth GRAVELLE, Lucy BAPTISTE and Elizabeth PHILLIPS - (Indian Girls) Escape from St. Eugene Indian School, Cranbrook, B.C., Asst. Dep't Indian Affairs.

15-9-36.

1. This a.m., I received a long distance telephone call from the N.C.O.L.C., Cranbrook Section, Cranbrook, B.C., to the effect that the above mentioned girls, all aged about sixteen years, had escaped from the school on the night of Sunday, Sept 13th, and were thought to be heading for the Tobacco Plain Indian Reserve, where their parents reside.

2. On receipt of the above I at once left per Police Car Code 1066 for the reserve, on my arrival at the reserve I interviewed Ambrose GRAVELLE (father) of Mary and Elizabeth, and guardian of Lucy BAPTISTE, and he told me that the girls had not as yet returned home, he further stated that he was at a loss to understand why the girls had left the school.

3. In company with Ambrose I visited the home of John PHILLIPS (father) of Elizabeth PHILLIPS, on our arrival there we were informed by (Mrs.) John Phillips that the girls had arrived at their place on Monday evening of the 14th instant in an exhausted and starving condition, having walked all the way from Cranbrook. On me telling them that the girls would have to be taken back to Cranbrook, they asked to be allowed to keep them home for a few days until they got rested up after their long walk, saying that they would take the girls back to Cranbrook themselves not later than Saturday Sept. 19th, to which I consented. I telephoned the Indian Agent at Cranbrook informing him of the present whereabouts of the girls, and that the parents would be bringing them up to the school not later than Saturday Sept. 19th.

Cranbrook, B.C.,
October 5th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Further to my report for the month of September I beg to advise that there were six desertions from the Kootenay Indian Residential School during the month. On or about the 20th instant four young girls of the Tobacco Plains Reserve left the school some time during the night and returned to their homes on the reserve two days later - distance of sixty-five miles. I am told that the girls were picked up by some friends the second day of their journey and taken to their homes where, in the company of Constable Ingles of the R.C.M.P., I called and brought them back to the school.

A week later two other girls of about fourteen years of age left the school very early in the morning and started for their homes on the Shuswap Reserve, almost a hundred miles away and were intercepted two days later by Mr. Sinclair, who is Game Warden at Canal Flats and kept at his home until the Principal of the school, Rev. Father Murphy, O.M.I., was able to call for them and bring them back. Canal Flats is between 55 and 60 miles from the school.

I am at a loss to know why there should have been so many desertions in so short a time as the Sisters in charge appear to be very capable teachers and very considerate.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No.155-0-10 of October 16th I may say that I have had several discussions with the Principal regarding the action of the girls in running away from the school and the more we think of it the more we are convinced that their action was due to a certain nervousness in meeting the Sisters. They were not accustomed to their garbs and, at the beginning, were uncomfortable in their presence. Since they have returned to the school, however, and become better acquainted they appear to be getting along very nicely, and in so far as truancy is concerned, I do not anticipate any further trouble.

Yours very truly,

Andrew Irwin,

File References Re: Mary A. JUSTIN & Anastasia MOSES - Indian Girls Runaways from St Eugene Indian School, Mission, B.C.

Headquarters

1. On the morning of 22nd instant I was informed by Mr. A. Irwin, Indian Agent for this district, that he had been notified that the two Indian girls named above had run away from the St. Eugene School, near Cranbrook, during the late evening of Monday, 21st instant. Their ages were about fifteen and ten respectively. Mary JUSTIN was the daughter of the Chief of the St. Mary's Reserve, on which the school is situated. The other girl's home is at Columbia Lake.

Sub-Division

2. Acting on Mr. Irwin's suggestion, I understand, the principal, Rev. Father Murphy, got in touch with the Chief and the latter instituted search of the Reserve. In late a.m. of 22nd inst., Reg. No. 11256 Cst. McLeod, and myself, patrolled the vicinity of the Reserve per Police Car Code No. 3208, with view to locating the missing girls. On arrival at the School in early p.m. to maintain contact, it was learned that the Chief had located the girls and had just returned them to the school and handed them over to the Principal. Our patrol then returned to detachment.

Detachment

P.C.R.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School which explains itself.

Due to an epidemic of Measles on St. Mary's Reserve during the end of August and early September, the School was closed by direction of the Medical Officer for St. Mary's pupils until October 1st. Despite this precaution, however, as stated by Reverend Principal Collins an epidemic of Measles broke out in October when the St. Mary's children returned to school. It is, therefore, true that every known precaution was employed to spare the pupils the risk of coming down with the disease and to keep the pupils out of the school. When all efforts failed and 38 were taken down with Measles one cannot speak too highly of the untiring efforts of the Principal and staff to nurse the children back to health and strength and their splendid success in dealing with the pneumonia cases.

If, under such unforeseen and trying circumstances, the Department can see its way to meet the wishes of the Principal with respect to some sort of financial adjustment for September, such action is possibly necessary to enable the School to continue their wholesome and healthful standard of living conditions for the pupils which has been so appreciated by each and all who have visited the school during the last 2 years.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Irwin:

I should like you to give your usual careful attention to this letter, and would ask you to place it before the proper authorities.

As you are well aware, the Measles epidemic closed our school for a considerable length of time, and in consequence, we received no grant for that period. It has been a very serious loss to this institution, for although we did not have the usual high food bill, yet the many other overhead expenses were just the same.

During the month of September, the salaries of the entire staff had to be paid, as well as their board. The usual overhead was present in fuel, light, water, etc. The clothing item was no smaller.

From past experience, it has been found that it requires the full quota of children to make ends meet. From 1929 until 1935 the Principal was unable to draw any salary; and during that time, and even at present, practically the entire produce of the Oblate Fathers' farm went for school upkeep without any remuneration to the Oblate Fathers.

The school was closed through no fault of ours; but in spite of the quarantine, the epidemic of measles broke out when the children returned. Some thirty eight of the children went down with it and although several severe cases of Pneumonia resulted, we were very fortunate in having no deaths.

As the medical advisor of the Department authorized the closing of the school, would not the Department look on the closing
as an extension of the Summer holidays and give us the grant as for July and August.

Owing to the quarantine, our average attendance of pupils for the September quarter was but fifty five, (55). Had there been no epidemic, our average attendance would have been seventy three, (73). We received grant for fifty five only.

I feel that I have a very strong case, and I trust that the Department will see their way to making a financial adjustment.

Thanking you in anticipation,

I remain,
Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa,
January 14, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Kootenay residential school with reference to the loss of grant occasioned the school as a result of an outbreak of measles on certain reserves which prevented the pupils from these reserves returning to the Kootenay school when the school re-opened after the holidays. The Principal's request has been given very careful consideration but present regulations do not permit our paying grant when pupils are absent from a residential school for any reason. The only exception is in the case of the two months' holiday leave for which grant is allowed.

I note that in spite of the fact that the children were kept out of school for some weeks measles broke out in the school following their return. This emphasizes the statement made by our Medical Superintendent in the third paragraph of his letter to you dated August 30 last. As the pupils were not allowed to return to the school on the first of September it is apparent that there were no results from the meeting attended by Dr. Green, the Principal and yourself. However, as pointed out above while the Department sympathizes with the Principal in the financial loss that he has suffered there is nothing can be done about the matter at the present time.

Yours truly,

A. Irwin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B. C.

At present in the Kootenay Indian Residential School, we are able to maintain an average attendance of ninety five children. In June, there are only two eligible for discharge; while in September we can expect up to ten new pupils. That means we will be housing at least one hundred children in our school. Cranbrook, B.C.,
Aug. 16, 1939.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In this Agency we have an Indian Residential School with an excellent teaching staff and accommodation for at least 100 pupils. The present quota is only 90. In the Okanagan Agency there are more children than can be accommodated in their schools. Twelve from Westbank and Similkameen desire to come to Cranbrook. There is no other place that they can go; Kamloops is overcrowded. My understanding is that those children will have to remain on their Reserves until arrangements can be made for their admission to some Residential School with its quota raised from 90 to 100. Our School could take care of them.

It would be a wonderful thing for those children, as well as for our School, if each might benefit by provision being made for their admission by increasing our quota from 90 to 100. I agree with the Reverend Principal Collins that if, at all possible, this should be done. May I, therefore, stress the urgent necessity for an increase of grant for this purpose?

Kindly advise in the matter and oblige.

Yours faithfully,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re your File No. 155-0-10.

In reply to your letter of July 25th, and return of voucher covering an item of $20.00 for transportation of School children from the Kootenay Indian Residential School at Cranbrook, B. C., to the Lower Kootenay Reserve at Creston, B. C., a return trip of 140 miles, kindly be advised that this account has not been paid.

Reverend Father Collins, Principal of the School paid the Railway Company $86.75 for tickets to transport 14 persons from Cranbrook to Penticton as shown on the attached receipts. The item of $20.00 is for transporting the children from the School to the above Reserve with his own car and a second car owned and driven by the Reverend G. Rogers, an Indian missionary located at the School. If the Department will kindly forward cheque to the School, including the $20.00 earned by the Reverend Principal and Father Rogers, the Principal will be glad to acknowledge the same on receipt. Kindly advise if this will be satisfactory and oblige.

Yours faithfully,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

In checking the December quarter return of the Kootenay Residential School it is noted that Josephine Dominic, No. 0252, was shown as 16 years of age on the September return but appears as 15 years of age on the December return. The original application form submitted for this girl shows that she was 16 years of age in 1934 at the time of her entrance to the school which would make her 16 years of age last September.

There may be special reasons for wishing to retain her in the Kootenay School for a further period but I would point out that in that event formal application should be made to the Department and our permission obtained. Please discuss this matter with the Principal and let me have the reasons for wishing to keep the girl after the age of 16 years.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr Phelan,

Would you please have $1500.00 of the December grant advanced to me towards the end of the month as I have only about $300.00 on hand and have some debts to pay. Thanks to the $3500.00 obtained from the Oblates, all the old bills have been paid. It is financially difficult to run this school as we are buying our meat and vegetables—although it looks as if the Oblates will have to pay for the latter.

Through the letters of the Vernon Indian Agent, you are acquainted with the case of the three Steele girls. They did not return this year but I suggested that it would be better for them to return on account of home conditions even though they were said to be attending a day school. The mother is dead, the father is in the army and, I am told, their Aunt is not fit to look after them. The Agent submitted the case to the Department and, recently, told me that the Department had ordered them to be returned to this School. The Agent promised to have them taken to Penticton and asked me to provide an escort from Penticton to Cranbrook. (This is always done especially as the train gets into Nelson at about 7 or 8 p.m., and stays there for about 6 hours). I wrote to our Agent saying that, while I was really anxious, for the good of the girls (whose guardian aunt I am informed was recently arrested for her part in a drunken brawl), to have them return, I could neither send an escort nor pay for their transportation particularly as they would not be grant-earning pupils as we now have our pupilage of 83.

The Department grants us only $90.00 for the transportation of all pupils during the entire year. As the Indian fare for children over 12 is $17.00 per child per year to and from Penticton, the grant does not pay for transportation of the Okanagan pupils one way. Then, the return fare of the escort has to be paid. I had Father Murray go twice to Penticton, Vernon, etc. for children since Sept. 1st. The natural reply is that the parents should be made to pay at least something towards transportation. I have seriously tried here and elsewhere to have this done but have failed. So have others.

In my letter to the local Indian Agent, I requested that, in view of the serious danger in which I am told these three girls are, the Department pay their fares and also allow a grant for them. I submitted also that, in view of the unfortunate financial condition of this school and the small pupilage, the Department is asking too much when it expects us, with a transportation grant of only $90.00, to pay the fares of the Okanagan pupils. I would greatly prefer to receive no transportation grant and to have the Department handle the transportation problem.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

P.S. So far, we have had no illness. The Provincial Police have just called ringing the fire alarm. They appeared satisfied with the fire alarm system, recently installed, with the way the pupils responded.

April 16, 1942.

Dear Sir:

For the past two or three years the Department has been allowing an amount of $90.00 a month for travelling expenses of pupils to and from the Kootenay Residential School for holidays. The Principal has written to us on different occasions and stated that this amount is not sufficient. The amount provided for travelling expenses in our appropriation is limited. However, we do not wish to do an injustice to any particular school. I should, therefore, appreciate your discussing the matter fully with the Principal and advising me the amount that you think should be allowed. I cannot promise you that this sum can be granted but very careful consideration will be given to your recommendation in this particular regard.

The Department has always felt that the parents should show sufficient interest in their children's education to take them home for holidays and return them on the expiry of their leave. Certainly there should be no difficulty in having the parents take the children home and, if they do not call for them, the children should remain in the school. There may be more difficulty in having them returned and, in that event, it may be necessary to pay transportation costs.

As pointed out above, the matter will receive further consideration when you reply.

Yours truly,

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
May 19th, '42

Kootenay Indian School
Cranbrook, B.C.

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

In his letter of April 16th (155-0-10), Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division, asked us to discuss my contention that $90.00 a year (and not per month as the copy of the letter states) is not sufficient to pay for the pupils' transportation. I presume that, as in other schools this amount is half of what was formerly granted.

"We are agreed that the parents should pay at least transportation costs, at least as a rule, especially as the Department and the School authorities not only furnish education free of charge but also clothe and feed the pupils. This was done during and before my time in the Cariboo School and I have sincerely tried to introduce this both in the Christie School and here. I have succeeded only in creating serious ill-feeling on the part of the Creston and some other Indians towards the School and the Department. For reasons to be given later, I have not even suggested that the Okanagans pay for their children's transportation. My experience is that it is neither advisable nor economical to try to force certain Indians to do their duty in this matter.

Let us take each reserve starting with the Kootenays.

St. Mary's reserve is adjacent to the School. Naturally, these people need no assistance from the Department.

Windemere reserve (Columbia Lake). With the exception of a few poor people, the parents bring their children to school and take them home. The one exception, last September, was Mrs. Martin Sam who receives a soldier's wife allowance and could easily pay. She and her children traveled a great deal and she finally sent her son by bus C.O.D. to Penticton from Vernon. We could not leave him stranded there and, so, Father Murray brought him with the Okanagan children. I need not say that it was useless to try to collect from her. I expect the same of her next year as she is still traveling and, I am told, carrying on while her husband is overseas.

Shuswap reserve—about 90 miles away. These people appear to expect us to bring their children to school. Some are poor and cannot visit their children during the year but I think that, if you take action, some at least could bring their children.

Tobacco Plains—about 65 miles away. In general, these people come for their children and bring them back but action should be taken against those who use as an excuse their having to bring their children to school in order to keep them home and out of school.

Creston—(Lower Kootenay)—about 65 miles distant. You will, I think agree, that these people, lazy, shiftless, apparently sitting around and doing nothing but waiting for their rental to be paid, are just about hopeless. There was very bitter feeling when I tried to insist that they come for their children last June. They did not come, while I do not like to give in to them, I do not see how we can get the children home or bring them back unless we do it ourselves. Their children do not seem to be taken care of at home during the holidays and, were it not for reasons given below, I would suggest that some be kept here during the holidays. They are taken to the orgy at Toppenish where there is drinking, immor-

Two of our pupils (one has not returned but recently asked to return to school), girls of 14 or 15, contracted gonorrhea during the last holidays. Other women are said to be in the same case. In spite of this, the parents would much prefer to keep their children out of school and on the reserve. They consider that they are doing us a favor by allowing us to take the children and, as a part payment for this, one man told me that the least we could do would be to pay the parents' fare from Creston whenever they wished to see their children here. You know the attitude. The best thing to do would be to use measures that would put sense into the Creston Indians' heads but what can be done? Leave the children at Creston where they will be undernourished and exposed to immorality and disease? I understand that they have a new Chief. I do not know him. When you see him, could you explain matters to him in such a way as to make him see things as they really are?

The Okanaganans. While there are some rather tough customers amongst these people, I think that they are much more sensible, advanced and well off than the Kootenays. However, I am very much in favour of not asking them to pay for their children's transportation even if they could do it. In the first place, we need these children both to get our pupilage, without which the school could not be financed, and also to raise the level of the school. It would be impossible to get them if we insisted that the parents pay $17.00 per child (and there are two to four of school age in these families) for the return fare exclusive of incidentals and at Indian rate. For children under twelve, the expense is half the above. This amount includes only the fare from Penticton and not from Inkameep, Westbank, Vernon, etc., to Penticton. Another factor is the attractions and the proximity of the Kamloops school to which many Okanaganans have gone and go. With its very large pupilage and consequent comparatively smaller overhead, this very efficient school can offer attractions which we cannot. But the main thing is its proximity to the Okanagan. Were I to state that Kamloops is ten or twenty times nearer than we are, a map would be brought out to show that, apparently, I was exaggerating. In reality, I am not. We have to consider the roads, the mountains, the ferries, the distance and the cost. What I mean will be understood, perhaps, if I state that more than twenty times the parents visit Kamloops than they do this School. Why? When several parents from Vernon wish to see their children (and these Indians do want to see their children in school especially as rumors come of the children's being ill, dead, maltreated, etc.), to cut down expenses, several get into an automobile and drive there, over good roads, in less than three hours. It takes an hour or two more from other reserves. When they get to Kamloops, they can get hospitality from the Shuswap Indians whom they know (probably as former schoolmates or as relatives) and spend little money. If parents wish to come here, each one has to get to Penticton and each has to pay about $17.00 for railway fare alone at Indian rate. Then, there is food for the journey and no hospitality from or friends among the Kootenay Indians. The best proof of this is that, since my coming here, only one Okanagan has come to visit her child. There is another point. Being so close to the Okanagan, the Kamloops School sends a bus or truck and picks up the children or puts them off at their houses and not at the Penticton station as we do. It would not be practical or, I understand, lawful for us to send a truck to the Okanagan as the trip would take a couple of days at least and the children would have to sleep somewhere at night. Even if no one else did, the parents would rightly object to this. It is bad enough when they come by train as they leave Penticton at 7 a.m. and arrive here about 25 hours later.
It hardly worth while mentioning a suggested solution make the parents bring their children to school and take them home whether they attend the Kamloops or the Kootenay School. The cost of taking them to Kamloops, especially as many would be crowded into an auto, would be negligible as compared with the cost of taking them to Penticton and then paying the railway fare to Cranbrook.

(There is no friction between the Schools or the Principals. In fact unable to accept all applications for admission, the Principal at Kamloops would willingly let all Okanagans come here and he would have done so last September had he not been wrongly assured that we were filled up and could not accept the Okanagans).

Even if we paid the transportation costs and Kamloops did not, it would be to the advantage of the Okanagan parents to send their children to Kamloops as they could easily visit them whenever they so wanted and as Kamloops can afford more attractions than can we. However, in order to be able to finance this School, we need the Okanagans and we shall need them especially as there have been about 25 deaths out of about 400 Kootenay Indians during the year ending last March and as more than 20 young men have joined the army from this Agency. The number of deaths and the number of births during the last year tell their story. We need the Okanagans and we shall not get them if we try to make them pay their railway fare. With a reduced pupilage of 83, this school cannot pay this amount.

Is the grant of $90.00 sufficient or fair? Exclusive of all other costs, I paid the C.P.R. $88.40 last June, for the transportation of the Okanagan children alone. In September, it cost me $81.15 plus $20.00 to bring back those who came at that time. Later, five others came from the Okanagan at an additional cost. In the above expenses is included about $17.00 for the transportation of an escort at clergy rate. An escort is necessary not only because they children spend 25 hours en route from Penticton or because there are young children but also because the train waits over in Nelson from about 7 in the evening until 1 or 2 in the morning. Although it takes only from about 4:30 a.m. until 10:15 at night to get back to Penticton, it is advisable to send an escort with so many young children.

I think that we could manage if the fares of the Okanagan children were paid but would appreciate an extra $20.00 to cover other cases such as those of poor families.

By the way, no word has come so far from Ottawa about the $20.00 per month salary grant for the nurse who attends to Indians on the Reserves. This has not been paid since April 1st, 1941, over a year ago. I sent her report in faithfully every month.

Yours truly,

G. Forbes, O.M.I.
May 19th, 1942
KOOTENAY INDIAN SCHOOL
CRANBROOK, B.C.

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

In the letter I wrote earlier in the day, I forgot the following. It was suggested in the copy of the letter which you passed on to me that we might keep those pupils here whose parents did not take them home for the holidays. I do not like the idea. First, it is punishing the children for the faults of their parents. Secondly, it would make us lose all the ground we have gained in dispelling the idea that this is not a jail or a detention home to which children MUST come. It is a place where they have the opportunity of improving their status in life. The third reason is the strongest. I believe that, quite naturally, the children kept here would run away and this idea of running away would occur to them and to others during the school term. We have had no runaways for some years now and, I hope, the idea has died. Knowing what I do of what happened here, at Mission, at Lejacq (where runaways froze to death), I cannot agree to the suggestion that we punish the children whose parents do not come for them by keeping them during the holidays. Attempts have been made, in the past, by dissatisfied Indians to burn down this School. That is another idea I do not wish to revive. Fourthly, if we kept the children here as a punishment, we should have even greater difficulty than we now have to get them back on time or at all in September. Unless I am mistaken, the Agent is ex officio a truant officer. His expenses and the expenses of the Police and the School would far exceed the original cost of transportation if we kept children here as a punishment. The same thing holds true in the case of the Creston lot and, for other reasons, of the Okanagan if we insist on them paying transportation costs. As facts prove, in both cases, the parents simply will not return their children. They will keep them at home without schooling and we shall find it as hard or harder than we did this year to get even our reduced pupilage. There are, as you are aware, perhaps twenty children at home who should be here in school now.

What specific amount would I suggest as a grant? It is impossible to set a fixed amount as the expenses vary with the number of Okanagan pupils and it is impossible to know exactly how many will be returning for each new term because some stay home without a real reason. This year, three sisters were kept by a relative (whose drinking and other alleged habits made her an unfit guardian) so that she might get an allowance for their keep because their father is in the army if, as I believe the story given me is true. Three brothers stayed at home (where I am told they do not attend school) because they wished to do so and, in order to stay at home, they told their father that one of our employees, no longer here, was "mean". In so far as I could find out, this was not true. It is hard to say how many will return as the parents seem to have a free hand in sending them to school or keeping them at school. The average cost, however, is about $200.00 for the Okanagan.

Yours truly,

G. Forbes, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

Dear Mrs. Phelan:

I have received a request from Millie Paul, pupil 0292, of Westbank, asking that she be allowed to return to this School for one more year although she is 16. She writes: "Father, I want to go back to School for one more year because it does me good." Last September, an aunt tried hard to keep the girl at home but the latter insisted & finally returned to School. I would recommend that her request be granted for the reason given - It is quite likely that we shall have more than the stipendage for which we are paid and that, in reality, the girl will cost the Department nothing.

I have mentioned the matter to Mr. Duncan Scott, Border and expect no objection from him. The girl has also requested that her 6-year-old cousin be allowed to come with her. The reason suggested is that Cranbrook is far from Westbank (near Vernon) and that the young boy's mother would be anxious if Millie were here during his first year.

The following from the girl's letter is typical of what I have heard from others. (Before the
Girls tell, I told them to give their mothers a holiday by helping them without their being asked to do so.

"I did all that you told me to do and mother is very pleased around here. I do all the cooking and housework. Mother is working out lessons but I help her there a bit too. Tell Sister Cynthia that I tried out her recipe (cooking) and it worked out pretty well for a start."

The fact that a 16-year-old girl asks to be treated seems to indicate that they are not treated too harshly here and that, for no reason she gave, they are trying to do what is right.

With kind personal regards,

Yours truly,
G. Forbes-Davil

Dear Sir:

There is a little Indian boy about ten years of age, known as Sam Pierre, staying with Indians Mr. and Mrs. Pat Abel on St. Mary's Reserve. His mother died some months ago and his father, an American Indian abandoned him.

This boy and his mother belonged to the Lower Kootenay Band as did his deceased father. The mother later married an American Indian who thus became responsible for the care of the boy. After his mother's death his step-father left him with the above mentioned Indian family and returned to the states. He makes no effort to sustain his step-son. In fact he was in gaol when his wife died.

The above family would adopt the boy if his step-father would consent, which he has not done. The boy is therefore stranded, and without a home. Under the circumstances, may he, whose mother and father were both Canadian Indians, be granted permission to attend the Kootenay Indian Residential School this year, until some arrangement for his future can be made?

Kindly advise and oblige,

I/L

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,

Dear Sir:

Would you please ask the Department to advance me $1500.00 on the September Quarter of the per capita grant?

The local missionary and some of the Tobacco Plains Indians have asked that we admit to this school a girl of about 9 who is running around the reserve and is not in school because of what I think is, in the case, a mere technicality. For the following reasons, I would suggest that, while this case be not considered a precedent, the girl be admitted.

She is the daughter of Pete Pierre and his wife. The father, an American Indian I believe, resided on the Tobacco Plains reserve for several years but, on account of bad conduct was not only not admitted to the band but was expelled from the reserve several years ago. While he has made short and infrequent visits to the reserve, I think that it can be said that he has abandoned his wife and family and that he in no way contributes to their support. The family is very poor and is supported by the mother's work and the charity of a few Indians. The mother is a Tobacco Plains Indian whose parents, as well as she and the young children, reside on the reserve. I might add that, several years ago, Father Patterson, then Principal here, went into the question very thoroughly and found that the mother was in no way to blame for the breaking up of the marriage. Two or three of the older children were admitted to this School.

While, technically, the mother, and, through her, the children, have lost their rights as Canadian Indians, they have been abandoned by the father and have no choice but to live on a Canadian reserve. The Department might be able to have the American authorities force the father to support the family and see that the young children receive an education. It seems to me that it would be far simpler to judge the case on its merits, relieve the mother of a burden and educate the children who, through the father's action, are practically abandoned children. I think that, including the girl mentioned, there is only one other child who may later wish to come here. The others are over school age.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Mr. Indian Agent Irwin has likely submitted the case of Teresa Pierre to you. Technically, this girl is not a Canadian Indian because her Canadian mother married an American Indian. He abandoned his family who have always lived in Canada (Tobacco Plains Reserve). The mother works hard and one or two Indians help her a little to feed and clothe her children but she is poor. Technically, she may have no rights but to all practical purposes she is a Canadian Indian.

And what can be done in this case? Mr. Irwin would quite naturally refuse to consider it on account of the very definite rulings of the Department. He has no right to disobey the Department. Has the Department the right to stretch a point? Two sisters were admitted to this school several years ago and they are still here. In the meantime, their Indian parents appear to have left the Tobacco Plains Reserve and have, I believe, thereby forfeited their Indian rights. They have sent me two younger children, who are now here and whom they do not wish to have separated from the other two who were admitted some years ago. Those admitted by the Department are Edna and Margaret Auld. The other two, whose names do not appear on the returns, are Rose and Lillian Auld. They are Canadian Indians but technically they are not. While I would like to have Teresa Pierre and the two Aulds admitted to the school by the Department, I do not wish to exaggerate - although they would find it difficult, I think that the Aulds could feed and clothe their children. I do not think that Teresa Pierre's mother could look after her daughter as she should. The little girl was thin when she came here and I think that
it will be found that she will soon be a T. B. case unless we look after her. I would very strongly recommend that Teresa be admitted. There are good reasons for keeping the Aulds but the case is not so urgent.

August 10, 1943

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 3 and April 19 with reference to pupils at the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

Regarding Agnes Stanley, No. 0245 and Millie Paul, No. 0292, the principal has not discharged these girls although it is doubtful if either of them will return to school. Agnes will soon be 17, really past school age. The condition of her home, however, is such that if she will agree to return to school, which is at present doubtful, it would be doing her a great kindness to grant her the privilege for another year. Agnes is quite a bright girl, and would possibly stand to benefit a great deal by one more year at school.

Millie Paul, No. 0292 is a member of the Okanagan Agency still under 16 years of age. Rev. Father Collins, Missionary Priest for the Indians there advises that he is hopeful but not at all sure he will be able to persuade the parents of this girl to allow their daughter to return to school. According to Principal Forbes, she will be very welcome if arrangements can be made for her return.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

School;

Although our school is functioning as efficiently as ever, a little trouble was experienced during the opening week. Three small boys aged eight, eleven and twelve apparently homesick decided to run away under cover of darkness, after an absence of two days there were met at Ta Ta Creek by an Indian on his way to Cranbrook and brought back to the School, after travelling more than fifty miles in the general direction of their home. Then again at the end of the month three of the older girls aged fourteen, fifteen and fifteen belonging to three different Reserves, The Lower Kootenay, Tobacco Plains and Columbia Lake, like the three young boys moved out under cover of darkness and have not so far been located although all roads leading in the direction of their homes are being carefully watched by the Indians and the Police. One of the run aways worked with her parents in the State of Montana for about three months in 1942, and it is thought that they may be heading in that direction, for this reason the emigration authorities at Rooseville have been requested to be in readiness to receive them if they pass that way.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OCTOBER, 1943.

School:

The Kootenay Indian Residential School has again settled down to its regular routine. On the occasion of my recent visit the Dormitories, Preventorium, Classrooms, dining room, kitchen, pantry etc., were all spotlessly clean and the excellent spreads on the Dining Room tables was proof conclusive that the children are not being stinted for food, on the contrary they are being well supplied with the necessary varieties of healthy, nourishing and appetizing things to eat.

The three run-away girls mentioned in my last report have since returned to school. They were picked up at McLeod, Alta., by a R.C.M.P. Police, and escorted back to Cranbrook by a priest.

The three young boys who were mentioned in my last report as having run away from school tried it again this month. The weather, however, was uncomfortably cold so much so that one little lad returned to the school of his own accord before completing his first night out. The other two were located and brought back the following day.

Main Roof repair work undertaken at the School by the Firm of Patmore Bros., in which only Tremco products were used has been in as far as one can tell at the present time satisfactorily completed. The job appears to have been well done, and it is not thought possible that further trouble in this connection will be experienced for many years to come.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Thank you for your letter of the 9th and for the enclosures about which I knew nothing as the writer had not mentioned the matter to me. While I did not suggest the change, it will, I think, meet with the approval of several employed by the Department as, after they had seen Father Anthony's work, these gentlemen suggested that Father Anthony be employed as Manual Training Instructor. Several Indians have suggested a change.

It is true that Father Anthony has a profession but, owing to his gifts as a cabinet maker and a carpenter, he has always had work where a church, a school or a rectory needed building or repairing with the result that, were he not stationed here as Manual Trainer, he would likely be sent elsewhere in the same capacity.

I have not asked that the 16-year-old pupils be discharged as several asked to be given permission to return in September. As I felt that they would change their minds during the holidays, I told them to write to me during the holidays to let me know whether they still wished to return for another term.

(Vancouver, B.C.) I shall likely submit the following case to Mr. Indian Agent Barber, although I do not know whether he will be able to do anything about it even though the "facts" given to me are as stated. At the request of the missionary, Father Collins, I allowed Eva Alec to come here. There seems to be no doubt that she is really an Indian but technically she is not. The story told me is that her mother was a bona fide Indian, with Indian rights, but lost her status by marrying a non-Indian. After she was deserted by this man, she lived with a bona fide member of the Penticton band and Eva was the result. If what I am told is true "Her father is a full-blooded Indian of the Penticton Indian reserve" but Eva is not considered an Indian by the Department although she is so considered by the Indians. I am not sure but I think that I was told that her parents were ordered off the Penticton reserve because of their co-habiting. Mrs. Edna Jack, who has children here, is a half sister of Eva and she wishes to have the girl given Indian rights. I am not asking that you do anything in the case unless and until Mr. Barber, who knows the case, brings the matter to your attention. I mention the matter because I intend to ask Mr. Barber to consider my request that, as an exception if necessary, the girl be admitted as a grant-earning pupil. He may have reasons not to request this favour of the Department.

Yours very truly,

G. Forbes, O.M.I.

October 4th, '944

Mr Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the September report, I believe that I should give you the following information.

The application for admission forms concerning the Okanagan pupils have been sent to their Agent, Mr Barber, or Vernon. I am sending the others to you with the exception of that of Isaac McKie. The boy's father told me that he had sent it directly to you but you have not received it. I have written to the father and spoken to the missionary and expect to have the form soon. The father has a daughter here and wishes the boy to be here.

Would you please ask that the following pupils be discharged? 233-Frank Toby, 13 years old; 234 Edward Moriceau, 16 years old; 244 Raymond Teneese, 16 years old; 252 Matthias Martin, 16 years old; 268 Zachary White who is ill and whom the Doctor would like to send to the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital; 0258 Ann Mary White and 0309 Clara "ack both of whom are 16 years of age.

261 Leonard Louie and 0282 Louise Qualtier were here some years ago and their parents wish them to be re-admitted. They have been given their former numbers. The boy's sister, Annabel, was here for a short time, about 4 years ago, but does not appear to have been placed on the register as she was a superfluous pupil, i.e., one for whom no grant was received because she was one of those above the approved pupilage. (It may interest you to learn or recall that she was then as bald as a billiard ball. Now, she has a good crop of natural hair).

A few are not yet 7. I request that they be admitted. One, who was 6 on Sept. 30th, is now 7. The mother did not wish to separate two sisters and, so, sent Clementine Jack (6) with Margaret (8). You know the rather sad case of Marietta Stanley (6). She is the daughter of the deceased Frank Stanley and of the valiantly struggling Mrs Frank Stanley. The mother is working for a living and has to look after her half-witted daughter Susan. Marietta is better off here with her sister Henrietta.

If it can be done, I suggest that, as an exception, 0346 Sabina David be admitted. Her deceased mother was a bona fide Indian—you likely remember her (nee Christine Goodman) of the Lower Kootenay Band of this Agency. The father, an American Indian, had a woman look after her in the U.S.A. But this woman died and he could find no one else. Finally, Louie Ernest, of the Lower Kootenay Band, adopted the girl Indian fashion. Her ration book lists her as Sabina Ernest (showing that Louie Ernest has adopted her). She appears to have no home.

Please get permission for 0345 Eva Alec to stay here at least until June. She will be 16 in December but has just come. She is an orphan and her guardian, who has children here, wishes her to be here. She is an Okanagan and I believe that Mr Barber may write to Ottawa about her. She is not here because she was misconducting herself.

As I mentioned to you, five should have their tonsils removed and about 13 (what a drop!) require dental attention. Please get the required authorization.
For a change, very few were late returning this year. Of those absent some are ill (Felix Capilo broke leg at home—now in hospital; Elizabeth Donc also was thrown from a horse—broken arm—at home; Lucy Swite ill at home—her cousin is at home waiting to accompany Lucy to school—they live near Vernon—Zachary White is the sole truant.

I am up to my neck in work and, so, close abruptly.

Yours [illegible], truly,

G. Forbes.

P.S. Mr. Irwin, I have just learned, has written very strong letter & fasting badly for White's parent.

S.J.

Mr. A. Irwin, Indian Agent, Cranbrook, B.C.

I am in receipt of the September quarter return of the Kootenay Residential School. The Department approves the discharge of the pupils numbered as follows:

No. 233 No. 268
" 234 " 0255
" 244 " 0309
" 258

The admission of the following children is also approved:

Elizabeth Joseph Harry Moriceau
Sabina Teneese Johnnie Sam
Noel John Justin Francis
Adrian Birdstone

With reference to Marietta Stanley, I note your statement that this girl is subnormal. We have just received a letter from the Principal with reference to this girl and he does not make any mention of her condition being such as you describe. The Principal states that there is an imbecile girl in the family, but he does not intimate that Marietta is the one. As a matter of face we inferred from the Principal's letter that Marietta is in good health and this appears to be borne out by the Medical Officer's report. The
only possible exception, as far as we know from the Principal, is that the girl is only five years of age and, in view of the special circumstances of this family, we feel that an exception should be made in her case and she should be accepted as a pupil, even though she is under age.

The case of Sabina David is considerably different. The information from both yourself and the Principal indicates that this girl's father is an American Indian. Her mother presumably was a Canadian Indian, but died two years ago. When all is said and done the responsibility for the maintenance of this girl rests with the father and as he is an American Indian he should be able to make arrangements for the education of his daughter. At the moment I cannot see how we would be justified in accepting her as a grant-earning pupil in the Kootenay School. There is some reference to the fact that the girl has been living with a relative, Louis Ernest of the Lower Kootenay Band. You might let me know the year in which Ernest first assumed responsibility for her maintenance. Has the girl lived with Ernest since that time and has the father contributed any amount toward her maintenance?

I understand that Eva Alee, who is a pupil of the school and is now fifteen years of age, will reach the age of sixteen in December. It has always been our practice to retain such pupils in the school until the following June 30. Consequently Eva Alee should remain in the Kootenay School until June 30, 1945.

Re: File No. 155-0-10

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, approving the discharge of seven pupils and the admission of seven to the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

With reference to the Stanley girl, the Rev. Principal writes as follows: You know the rather sad case of Marietta Stanley (5), she is the daughter of the deceased Frank Stanley and of the valiantly struggling Mrs. Frank Stanley. The mother is working for a living and has to look after her half witted daughter Susan.

The Principal was eager to have Marietta admitted although she is only five years of age. Susan, the imbecile, is fifteen years of age, a harmless, useless individual who cannot be left alone, thus causing her mother a great deal of worry and trouble. The Principal feels that he would like to relieve Mrs. Stanley of the responsibility of caring for this girl if the Department would approve of her admission to the school.

Regarding Sabina David, as soon as her relative Louie Ernest can be located will learn from him the date from which he accepted responsibility for her maintenance and whether or not her father has made any contributions.

With reference to application forms and certificates of health for the pupils mentioned, these will be forwarded with the School's monthly report.

Andrew Irwin,

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MOORE

Re: Lucy Swite, No. 0331, Kootenay Indian Residential School.

This girl was admitted to the Kootenay School on September 1, 1943. She is 14 years of age and comes from the Okanagan Agency.

In a letter dated December 31, 1944, just received from the Principal, Reverend G. Forbes, O.M.I., he writes as follows:

"I asked the Missionary, the girl's father and others not to let her return after the summer holidays in 1944, unless a doctor certified that she was physically fit to attend school. The local doctor had ordered her to remain in bed during her entire holidays. She returned to the school November 15 and we soon had to send her to the hospital. She left for home yesterday (December 30, 1944) but I was unable, as was the doctor at the school, to have her father take her to the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital. I fear that it may soon be too late to send her there. The mother died of T.B. within the last two years. There is serious danger of others contracting the disease if she remains at home. What can one do in such cases? There is a similar case on the local reserve."

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
January 6, 1945.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Pupils N.231- Moses Patrick and #0266 Edna Auld are now 16, and I would recommend the Rev. Principal be authorized to retain them until the end of the term.

Pupil #289, Felix Capilo suffered a severe fracture during the Summer holidays and owing to complications a steel plate was required. I am not in a position to say just what this boy's condition is today. The school year having so far advanced, I would recommend that Felix be allowed to remain at home until the next school term.

(J.D.Caldwell)

Dear Father Kelly:

The Department finds it necessary to send back the December quarter return of the Kootenay Indian Residential School. In the first place, we have only received a copy. The original return should be forwarded to this office.

In the preparation of the quarterly return I would direct your attention to circular letter of December 29, 1944, a copy of which I enclose, and also the notes on the preparation of the return which appear on the back of the form. It is extremely essential that the names of the pupils should be entered consecutively according to number. If you review page 3 of the attached return, you will note that the numbers are mixed up in such a manner that is extremely difficult to check the return. Please have the names of the pupils entered consecutively according to number. There is a special note regarding this matter on the back page of the return.

Form IA 411 should accompany all quarterly returns, giving the information requested on that form. This information should be the same as the information on the return.

No grant is requested for pupils No. 261 and 0282 and possibly some others, and no explanation is given for their absence.

The quarterly returns are being carefully scrutinized by the Auditor General and it is absolutely essential that they be correct. Besides, you will

Rev. G. Kelly, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, B.C.
appreciate the fact that it is in your own best interests to have this form properly and carefully prepared, as the per capita allowance due the school is paid on receipt of the quarterly return and the amount of this is computed from the information given on the return.

In order to assist you in your financing we are sending a cheque for part of the December quarter per capita allowance, and the balance will be sent to you when you send back this return, properly prepared.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

Please find enclosed corrected original copy of our quarterly report for the Oct. --Dec. quarter of 1945. I appreciate the direction you gave me when returning the report for correction and completion as it aided me greatly in making the report according to the desired method. As you know I have not been familiar with the compiling of these reports and there were certain points over which I was puzzled but your letter and the copy of the circular have cleared them up. I hope you find the enclosed in order but if there are still corrections to be made I will gladly accept its return and any further suggested adjustments.

Your letter mentioned that with each quarterly return there should be a copy of Form IA 4II. I mentioned this to our Agent but he said that as far as he understood that form only had to be sent when there was an admission or dismissal during the quarter reported. Since we have not had either admissions or dismissals during this quarter I am at a loss to know what should be entered. You will notice on the returns certain pupils who as far as I know are reported as attending day school in the Okanagan Agency and others of our own Agency who have failed to return. Since neither have been officially discharged by the Dept. I am still retaining their names on the quarterly sheets. At your convenience I would be pleased to have the matter of Form IA4II cleared up so that in future I will know precisely what to enter thereon.

No doubt you will recall my report of Sept. last on some of the difficulties with which we were confronted here. Since then we have had some very trying times with our light, heat, and water equipment. We have had a series of breakdowns and at one time we were for three days without light, heat, or water. That, in this climate, and with several children in bed with Measles at the time, is no small matter. I would like to write you further on these and relevant matters.

I am in receipt of a cheque from the dept for $3200.00 as an advance on this quarter. If this report is found in order I trust the balance will be forthcoming.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

AGENCY'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Welfare and Training

The Kootenay Indian School under the efficient leadership of Reverend Gerald Kelly, O.M.I., has made very steady progress during this quarter. The pupils are making rapid progress in their classes, most studies, domestic science, and manual training. The tubercular patients have shown very satisfactory improvements. There has been little or no sickness in school during this quarter except for five cases of measles, one reported on December 17th and four on December 29th. Antimarial serum was used on the contacts and it is hoped that this epidemic will reach no great proportions. The pupils are well nourished and their health is carefully looked after by Sister Marion Clare. The pupils were vaccinated against smallpox, and will be vaccinated against typhoid as soon as the measles is over. The school is well supplied with milk, eggs, vegetables and fruit.

This school carries eight pupils in excess of its quota. Three Auld children, who do not belong to the reserves, will be returned home as soon as the quarantine on measles permits. However, this still leaves us short of space for twelve pupils from the Columbia lake and Shuswap Reserves who should be returned to school, not only for their own good but as a matter of discipline. This matter has been referred to the Department and I am awaiting a reply before taking any action.

The fire extinguishers requisitioned for the school were finally received, and fire drills are held as per regulations. One unscheduled rehearsal was held at 5:00 o'clock one morning when the new fireman or night watchman inadvertently pulled the fire alarm. This proved to be a good and successful fire drill. In addition to the night watchman and fireman, Rev. Father Kelly has hired a new farm manager, who has good recommendations.

On my last inspection it was noted that good work had been done in redecorating the girls play room, several chairs having successfully been re-upholstered with bright materials. Kindergarten tables and temporary chairs as well as other objects have been fashioned in the Manual Training department. The domestic science department does excellent work in cooking under the direction of Sister John Anthony and Sister Catherine Mary's sewing class produced very good work. The pantry and hallway near the Father's dining room has also been redecorated.

The situation with reference to the plumbing at the school is still bad, even though some of the toilets were temporarily repaired, flush actions, etc., are so far unobtainable. One urinal near the boys dormitory was put in working order and all taps were replaced.
The situation with regard to power is worse; the Lister engine has not been in operation since it was repaired having run only for two weeks; the Petters engine, which is used to pump water, recently broke down, the fuel tank being gone. It is now undergoing emergency repairs. This leaves us entirely dependent on the old Otto engine which through Father Kelly's ingenuity was "rigged up" to pump water. This engine consumes gasoline at the rate of nearly a gallon an hour! So that between pumping water and charging batteries which will not hold their charge, it is pounding away from morn till dark. The Petters engine should be repaired in two or three days but the present situation emphasizes the gravity of the situation with reference to the electric generating plant. As this school is my request, Mr. John Ward of the Modern Electric recently submitted a report on this situation and copies of it were forwarded to the Commissioner's office. The water pump has recently caused quite a bit of anxiety; it was leaking so badly that it had to be primed before each pumping. It is a very ancient and heavy contraption and it is feared that the base is so corroded that it may give out altogether for the time being it has been packed with oakum, but it may become necessary to call in a welder to weld on a new base.

As a result of Commissioner MacKay's visit, authority was granted to install a new sink unit near the children's dining room. This will prove to be more sanitary and a great improvement for which we feel very grateful.

Rev. Father Kelly has given sporting activities more meaning in this school and he has recently purchased skates and toboggans which the children are enjoying.

J.M. Barre,
Acting Indian Agent.

C.F.R.yards also Chinatown twice in Cranbrook but could not locate
them,nor did he receive any definite information as to their
whereabouts,but had been told by other girls that their parents
resided at Creston,but were at present employed at Omak,
Wash.U.S.A.and that the girls might attempt to cross the Line
to the United States,or return to the Reserve at Creston.

Kingsgate,B.C.of the incident requesting that if located try-
ing to gain admission to the States that they be held and his
office notified,the writer notified Cpl.Whittaker,L/C.Creston
detachment,who is making a check in the Creston area,also
advising the Customs Port of Rykerts.

check of Chinatown,also the C.F.R.yards,and adjoining jungles
without result,certain Indians were interviewed but could not
offer any information as to their whereabouts,B.C.Police were
notified who in turn checked outgoing trains throughout the
night,without result.

Ottawa, 1 November 1946.

Mr. J.S. Dunn, Indian Agent,
CRANBROOK, B.C.

The Department approves the admission of the undermentioned children to the Kootenay Residential School:

Doreena Auld, Louise Pierre, Monica Nicholas, Vera Thomas, Martina Pierre, Norman Joseph, Hubert Joseph Pascal, Wilfrid Tennese, Agatha Basil, Peter Joseph Williams.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Kootenay Indian School,
Cranbrook, B. C.

Mr. A. Barber, Indian Agent.
Vernon, B. C.

Dear Mr. Barber:

As you probably know, Bertram Alec is in this school this year. While it is true he is not a full-blooded Indian, I would like to try to have him accepted. If you think it advisable would you consider signing the enclosed application forms and forwarding them to Ottawa. I doubt if he would have been accepted a few years ago but my present experience is that the Department is somewhat more lenient in such cases now. During the past year I was able to take in two 'aliens', Elizabeth Alec from Penticton, and one who was half American from Creston.

If they will accept Bertram I feel it would give him a chance as he is a rather backward child. If you would be good enough to explain the circumstances of his case to the Department, I would appreciate it very much.

With sincere thanks,

I remain,

Truly yours,

G. F. Kelly, O.M.I.
Principal.

Okanagan Indian Agency
Vernon, B.C.
October 31, 1946.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Herewith for consideration of the Department is an application for admittance to the Kootenay Indian Residential School of Bertram Alex, age 10, together with a letter received from Father Kelly, the Principal.

Bertram Alex, is the child of a Penticton woman married to a United States Indian, who claims to have been born on the Penticton Reserve. Although he has never been entered as a member of the Penticton Band, a brother and sister of the same parents were. He is entered on the rolls of the Colville (U.S.) Agency.

This child's mother died during its infancy, since when he has been brought up by Mrs. Holding, who lost her Indian Status on her marriage to a white man, a sister of Angus Alex, the child's father, living in the city of Penticton. She is a decent and respectable woman and has the child's welfare at heart. She had him attend the Penticton Public School for two years. However, the boy is much undersized and handicapped by badly crossed eyes, and has had a pretty rough time and does not fit in with the white boys at all.

In the interest of the child and in consideration of Mrs. Holding, who is very cooperative with this office and the church, I would recommend that Department authorise this child's admission to the Residential School, on condition that he is not to be considered as a member of the Penticton Band at this time.

This child also attended the Penticton Day School for a time but only as a favour on the part of the teacher who was aware that he was not on the Band Roll. He is, of course, Indian in every way and I expect, legally is an Indian of the Colville (U.S.) Agency, where his father belongs. However, it will be much in the child's interest if the Department will approve the attached application.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Indian Agent

Ottawa, January 31, 1947.

Dear Father Kelly:

The Auditor has reviewed the September Quarterly Return, 1946 and has questioned the number of days the under-mentioned pupils are entitled to:

Luke White,
Albin White,
Jacob White,
Augustine White,
Lawrence Jacobs,
Isaac McCoy,
Bertha McCoy.

With reference to circular letter 150-87 of December 29, 1944, it is pointed out that pupils attending School during the September Quarter are entitled to sixty-two days grant for summer holidays, plus the actual number of days the pupils are in school during September.

Ex. If a pupil returned to school September 15th he is entitled to sixty-two days plus sixteen, thus seventy-eight.

In the "Remarks" column of the September Quarterly Return, it is noted that you have made an entry opposite the names of the above mentioned pupils "Returned Late". In order to adjust this return, it will be necessary for you to forward the exact date on which the pupils returned to school.

Incidentally, the December Grant will go forward this week and any adjustment arising from the above will be deducted from the March Quarter Return.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. G. Kelly, O.M.I.,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

I am in receipt of yours of the 31st regarding further information as to the exact date of returning to school of certain of our pupils. I am sorry that I overlooked putting this information on the Quarterly Return for September. I was of the impression that absence in Sept. was considered on the same basis as hospitalization, that is, thirty days were allowed before subtracting from the grant, hence I granted them the ninety days.

Luke White returned Sept. 10th/46
Albin White
Jacob White
Augustine White

Lawrence Jacobs returned Sept. 14th/46

Isaac & Bertha McCoy returned Sept. 9th but were allowed out to assist their parents in harvesting potatoes. They have not yet returned to school. I guess the potato harvest must have been quite extensive. They were in residence eleven days in Sept.

I trust this information will clear up any misunderstanding in the matter.

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.

September 6th, 1947.

Mr. J. S. Dunn,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B. C.

Dear Mr. Dunn:

Re: Children of Douglas Phillips,
Tobacco Plains.

Mr. Douglas Phillips of Tobacco Plains has requested the admission to school of his two children, Sally May Phillips and Sadie May Phillips, aged seven and eight. Though not full blood Indians both he and his wife, the former Mary Gravelle, were accepted as pupils at this school some twelve and fifteen years ago. They are not living within reach of a day school and if accepted by the Dept. they would be glad to send their children here. From present indications our enrollment will fall short of our quota this year and I would be willing to have these children with us. Would you mind taking the matter up with the Dept. so that we may have their ruling on it as soon as possible.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd) G. F. Kelly, O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev. Father Kelly, Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, requesting authority to admit Sally May Phillips and Sadie May Phillips of Flagstone to his school.

The father of these children, Douglas Phillips, is part Indian, was born adjacent to the Tobacco Plains Reserve and attended our Residential School some fifteen years ago. The mother, formerly Mary Gravelle, is the daughter of Ambrose Gravelle, a member of the Tobacco Plains Band, Kootenay Agency, who also attended our Residential School some years past.

As these children are more Indian than white, and as school facilities are not readily available to them and there is room for them at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I would recommend that their admittance be authorized if at all possible.

J. S. Dunn,
Indian Agent.

Encl.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

Enclosed is a copy of a letter received from

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Your File 155-8-10(W.T.I)

Replying to your letter of the 26th inst., with respect to the admission of the children of Douglas Phillips to the Kootenay Indian Reserve School, I would advise that this matter was discussed in the status investigation of the Tobacco Plains Band recently submitted to the Department, in which it is shown that Douglas Phillips is not an Indian within the meaning of the Indian Act, and his wife Mary Gravelle is a daughter of a United States Indian, although it was recommended that she be considered entitled to share in the funds of the Band.

Under the circumstances I am at a loss to know why Indian Agent Dunn should have recommended the admission of these children as grant-earning pupils, as, in my opinion, they are definitely not entitled to same.

D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, October 2, 1947.

Mr. J.S. Dunn, Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

On receipt of your letter of September 10th, file 0-11-1, regarding the request for the admission of the Phillips children to the Kootenay Residential School we wrote to Indian Commissioner MacKay.

We are now informed that the father of these children is not an Indian within the full meaning of the Indian Act and that the mother is the daughter of a United States Indian.

Under the circumstances the Department does not consider these children as eligible for admission as grant earning pupils to a residential school.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
