Mr. A.H. Barber, Indian Agent,
Vernon, B.C.

Dear Mr. Barber:

Please find enclosed application for admittance to this school of two children from your agency, Fredrick Swite and Wilfrid Squakim. Would you please complete these and send them to Ottawa. There is a rather queer circumstance regarding Wilfrid Squakim. As you will notice he is not yet six years of age but his mother was very anxious to have him come. I understand that the grandmother of some of the relatives have been taking care of him. While she was pleased to have him come and asked me personally if we could take him she was reluctant to sign the admission papers so Father Collins sent them to me as is. Perhaps you could add a note to this effect or if she is within contact explain the necessity of having these papers signed.

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.
Vernon, B. C.
October 17, 1947.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

With reference to the attached application for admission to the Kootenay Residential School of Wilfred Squakim and Frederick Alfred Swite.

She is in very poor health and it is in the interest of the child that she be admitted to the Residential School and approval is recommended.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM - Mr. W. S. Arneil:

Re: Admissions to Residential Schools.

I refer to Mr. Sampson's letters of December 5 and 7 concerning the above. You will note from his letter of December 5 that six children have been withdrawn from the Provincial School at Enderby and admitted to the Kamloops Residential School without reference to the office of the Superintendent of the Okanagan Agency. The home conditions of these children do not require their enrolment at a Residential School. In addition his letter of December 7 shows that children who should be attending the Inkameep Indian Day School have been admitted to the Kootenay Indian School without reference to him.

In the case of the six children admitted to the Kamloops School, these admissions, in addition to involving an unwarranted expenditure of public funds, have denied accommodation to children who should be in the Kamloops Residential School either because home circumstances require that the children be given institutional care or because there is a lack of Day School facilities on the Reserve.

In the case of the two children admitted to the Kootenay Residential School, you will recall an interview in your office with the Principal in which you specifically requested that he draw no children from the Inkameep Reserve as we were most anxious to get the Inkameep School running on a sound basis.

To my mind these are shocking examples of lack of cooperation on the part of the church authorities and I feel there must be a definite statement of policy by the Department with regard to the admission of children to Residential Schools if these institutions are to fill the function expected of them. These regulations should
require that (1) no child shall be admitted to a Residential School without reference to the Superintendent of the Agency in which the child resides and (2) should a child be admitted without reference to the Superintendent no per capita grant will be paid for that child.

In addition to the above statement of general policy, in these two cases I recommend that these pupils be discharged from the Residential Schools at the close of the present term and be re-admitted to the schools they should be attending, effective January 1, 1951, and that no per capita grant be paid to Residential Schools for these children for the current quarter.

R. F. Davey,
Regional Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

Re: Admissions to Residential Schools

I attach hereto a memorandum dated December 8th from our Regional Inspector of Schools, Mr. Davey, together with a copy of a letter dated December 7th from Indian Superintendent Sampson, with application forms attached for admissions to residential schools.

It will be noted from Mr. Davey's memorandum that the eight children affected were admitted to residential schools without reference to the Agency office and further that it is considered the home conditions of these children were satisfactory and that adequate provision existed for their education locally. In the case of the five Jones' children and the Beatty boy from Enderby Reserve, it will noted that they have attended Enderby Public School for periods ranging from three to nine years.

Leaving the financial aspect aside, I feel perhaps the most regrettable feature is the fact that eight other Indian children are being at present deprived of any education at all. With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Kootenay Indian Residential School we have not received the necessary application for admission for pupil # 371 Felix Abel consequently his admission to the school has not been approved. The Principal has claimed twenty-six days grant for this boy, however as his admission to the school has not been approved the per capita grant on the September Quarterly Return for him is being disallowed. It would be appreciated if you would arrange to have the necessary application prepared and forwarded to this office for consideration and advise the Principal that it will be in order to include this boy's name on the December Quarter claiming per capita grant for the December Quarter and twenty-six days for September. The necessary explanation should be shown in the Remarks Column.

The Principal has shown # 0345 for Margaret Jack. Our records indicate that this pupil's number is 0343. The Principal has shown 0353 for Martina Pierre. Our records indicate the register number for this girl is 0355. Please advise the Principal to amend his copies of the Return.

The Principal has claimed fourteen days grant for pupil # 0370 Merle Gravel and indicated that this girl was admitted to this school on September 4th. It is evident that either she entered the school late or was truant, consequently we are disallowing any grant for her until the matter is clarified. Please instruct the Principal that it will be in order to claim fourteen days grant or whatever grant is entitled to the school on the December Quarterly Return indicating in the Remarks Column.
the exact date for claiming the number of days. It will be in order for the Principal to claim the usual per capita grant for the December Quarter on the same Return.

Re: Sebastian JACK — Penelakut Band

Further to our correspondence pertaining to the above-named boy who was to be sent to the Kootenay Residential School at the same time as Ronald Baker of the Squamish Band, it has been necessary to cancel the arrangements for Sebastian as well as for Ronald.

Sebastian was not physically examined for purposes of school admission by Dr. Coddington, Indian Health Services, but a fairly recent medical report on file at the Boys' Industrial School indicated no physical disabilities and that the boy was in good health. A reservation had been made for Sebastian to leave Vancouver via C.P.R. on November 5th, but on the afternoon of November 4th, we received a telephone call from the Boys' Industrial School advising that a routine examination prior to discharge from the school indicated that Sebastian had an enlarged heart, and the doctor recommended specialist treatment and advised again transporting the boy by airplane to Cranbrook. The Industrial School had no explanation for the fact that this condition had not been diagnosed on previous occasions, but we did not feel that he should be sent to the Kootenay School until such time as further examinations can be made by a heart specialist. Consequently, it was necessary to cancel arrangements made for the admission of Sebastian to the Kootenay School.

Re: Ronald BAKER — Squamish Band

With reference to our correspondence pertaining to the above-named boy, arrangements were made for his admission to the Kootenay Residential School, physical examination completed and air transportation reservation made. These plans had all been undertaken with the full co-operation of Ronald's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. William Baker, who have cared for the boy since infancy.

The family was visited yesterday and advised at that time that they had changed their minds about sending the boy to Cranbrook as they felt it was too far for him to go. They seemed quite aware of the consequences that they would have to take if the boy became ill, but they still continued to refuse to carry out the plan of school admission; consequently, this boy will not be admitted to the Kootenay School as previously arranged.

Dear Father Dunlop:

The Department has recently instructed that the enrolment of Indian children at residential schools be reviewed. In looking over the list for Kootenay School, I find that there is no justification for the following children to be attending:

Jean and Arthur Parker
Violet, Winifred, Ethel & James Thomas
Grace, Margaret, Clementine & Roy Jack.
Arbelle Felix.

The parents of these children have been informed that you are being asked to discharge the children as of June 30th, 1953. Arrangements are being made to send them to local day and public schools.

August 20, 1953.

Mr. Philip Phalen Supt.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
McFarland Bldg.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

Please find enclosed a letter I received from Superintendent Sampson a few weeks ago.

May I point out that with the exception of the Parker children, there is no justification for holding back the other children listed. The Thomas children and Arbelle Felix are from Enderby. This Reservation has no Catholic day school. It is true that the Jack family belong to the Penticton Band where there is a Catholic day school. However, Mr. Jack has had steady employment elsewhere for several years. It seems unreasonable to ask him to give up steady employment and return to the Penticton Reservation in order that his children attend the day school there.

I have a letter from Mr. Jack in my files specifically asking me to take this matter up with the Department on his behalf. In this letter he explains his situation, and is most anxious that his children return to this school.

I am most anxious to have these children attend this school again. Anything you can do concerning this matter will be greatly appreciated.

Yours truly,

G. P. Dunlop, O.M.I.
Principal.
August 27th, 1953.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver 2, B.C.

Re: Kootenay Indian Residential School

Further to my letter of August 24th concerning the discharge of certain children belonging to the Okanagan Agency from the above named residential school, I have now received a letter from the Principal with which he encloses a letter he has received from Mr. Sampson. I am forwarding herewith copies of these two letters.

In view of the concern which you have had about the enrolment at the Kootenay School, and the correspondence which you have had with Mr. Sampson concerning this matter, I feel that Mr. Sampson's action in writing to the Principal without consulting you was unnecessarily hasty.

I shall appreciate having your recommendation as to what action should be taken with regard to the discharge of the children who Mr. Sampson feels should be released. It is felt that you should also inform Mr. Sampson that he should not arrange for the discharge of children unless he has departmental approval for so doing. In this connection, you might draw Mr. Sampson's attention to Section 10 of the regulations with respect to residential schools. The use of Superintendent in this section refers to the Superintendent of Education, as indicated in the definition given in Section 2.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Barry's report regarding his visit to the Kootenay Indian Residential School on the 21st ultimo.

It appears from this report that Mr. Barry discussed with you the qualifications of the present manual training instructor. He further reports that you told him you might be able to obtain the services of a trained manual training instructor from the Cranbrook Provincial Schools.

The Department considers that this latter arrangement would be preferable to retaining the present manual training instructor, who appears to be insufficiently qualified for the position.

Mr. Barry also reports that there is a possibility of obtaining the services of a blacksmith to instruct the boys in general farm blacksmithing, including the shoeing of horses. The Department considers that instruction of this kind would likely be very useful to the boys attending the Kootenay School.

I would appreciate hearing from you what action you intend taking in connection with the above matters.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Michael Murphy, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kootenay Indian Res. School,
Cranbrook, B. C.

PP/O'M.
The Manual Training is at present under the care of a young man, Mr. Patrick Grant. The only qualification that Mr. Grant would appear to have is the fact that he was for four years at the Vancouver Technical School. He is certainly not the kind of Instructor we require in the Indian Residential Schools. I understand that he wants to leave, does not care for the work, etc., or at least so I am informed by the Principal.

The Manual Training Shop has been previously reported upon by me. It is some 24 feet by 36 feet with six large double benches. There is a good blackboard, and the building is heated by a wood burning stove. It was not very tidy when I visited the place. I suggested that the shavings and small pieces of waste wood be burned and not left about on the floor. I made a point of asking the instructor about the condition of the tools. He was not very definite but appeared to consider them in a satisfactory state. I consider that they are in anything but a satisfactory state, and I suggested that he have the boys learn to keep the tools properly, and now proceed to sharpen them Etc. The three or four tools that I examined at random were in a very bad state indeed, half moons out of chisels, etc.

It would appear that twenty-one boys in two classes of twelve and nine are taught for two half days from November to March and I expressed the fact that I was not very well satisfied with this work and the Principal told me that there was a chance that they might obtain the services of a TRAINED MANUAL INSTRUCTOR from the Cranbrook Provincial Schools for a weekly visit on Saturdays. This would be a splendid arrangement, and I would ask that the Department insist on some such change at the earliest possible moment. The Indian Agent would no doubt be able to arrange this matter for the Department. He is I believe in agreement with me in the matter, which I have talked over with him in broad outline.

There also appears to be the possibility of obtaining the services of a blacksmith to instruct the boys in general farm blacksmithing, including the shoeing of horses. I certainly agree with the Indian Agent that this is the sort of instruction which would be of the very greatest use to the boys when they leave school. I would ask the Department to also communicate with the School and the Indian Agent with regard to this activity, which I wish to very strongly recommend for this school. The question of the starting a shoemaking shop is being left to next year, as I wish to have the boys instructed in the above first.
THE KOOTENAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
CRANBROCK, B.C.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Barry's report regarding his visit to the Kootenay Indian Residential School on the 22nd ultimo, and it appears that when he visited the manual training shop it was very untidy and there were shavings on the floor. It is considered that the manual training instructor should have the pupils clean up the room previous to dismissal of the class.

The Inspector also comments as follows regarding the work of the manual training class:

"There are dozens of places in the school where the Manual Training Class could carry out repairs, mending floors, fixtures for the classrooms, etc. I suggested to the Principal that the boys, under their Instructor could carry out numerous repairs without cost to the Department. If they are unable to do this the present system had better be changed. I think there has been too much time spent in foolish little models like the work done in Provincial Schools."

The Department agrees with the above remarks, and the matter should be drawn to the attention of the Principal.

Please let me know the name of the manual training instructor at the Kootenay School. In Mr. Barry's report he states the name is J. S. Manson, but it is noted that the voucher forwarded monthly from your office shows the manual training instructor's name as J. Cullen.

Yours truly,

A. Irwin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
The Manual Training is now under the care of J. S. Manson, the Manual Training Instructor of the Cranbrook Schools. This is in accordance with my own recommendations as stated in my last report.

The Manual Training Shop is some 24 feet by 36 feet with six large double benches. There is a good blackboard. The building is heated by a wood-burning stove. When I visited the shop it was very untidy, shavings on the floor. I am certainly very surprised to find that any trained teacher of Manual Training would leave the place as I found it. The Principal explained that the school was at fault and that the shavings should have been gathered up in the afternoon following the class. I do not agree and consider that the Manual Training instructor, or in fact any teacher, should have his class clean up the room previous to dismissal. As this matter of an untidy Manual Training Shop was reported last year, I would ask that the Department take the matter up through the Indian Agent, who will of course have a copy of this report. It was not mentioned to Mr. Irwin at the time, owing to the fact that there were so many other points to be discussed. The tools, reported in poor condition last year, have been, I understand, overhauled and repaired. Numerous missing parts have been replaced. They were locked up and I was unable to see them.

I am not very well satisfied with the work being done here in Manual Training, though I admit it is an improvement on that of last year. There are dozens of places in the school where the Manual Training Class could carry out repairs, mending floors, fixtures for the classrooms, etc. I suggested to the Principal that the Boys, under their Instructor could carry out numerous repairs without cost to the Department. If they are unable to do this, the present system had better be changed. I think there has been too much time spent in foolish little models like the work done in Provincial Schools. This is clear from the attached Manual Training Report handed to me at the school.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Kootenay Indian Residential School on November 9 and 10 Inspector Barry writes as follows:

"I believe that it would be better to dispense with the services of Mr. J. S. Manson who is the Provincial manual training instructor in Cranbrook and comes out to the school each Saturday. The Principal complains about the trouble of transporting the instructor to and from Cranbrook weekly. I believe the Department's grant for manual training at this school is being wasted."

Please discuss the above report with the Reverend Principal and let me know what steps you consider could be taken to make the manual training more effective. Is it possible to secure a qualified manual training teacher to replace Mr. Manson? It is understood, of course, that his services should be retained until you have reported further to the Department and our decision has been given.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

7th January 1939

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Irwin:

I was very much surprised at the rather severe criticism of our Manual Instructor by the School Inspector, Captain Barry.

Mr. Manson has been for years the Instructor in the Public School of Cranbrook. As such he is thoroughly qualified, and were he not, it is surprising that the Provincial School authorities have been satisfied during all this time. Mr. Manson has been carpentry instructor here in the Kootenay Residential School for many years. Is it only now apparent that he is useless and that the money paid by the Department for a Manual Instructor is being wasted?

Captain Barry considers this money as being wasted. I wonder if the following construction works by the Indian boys of this school testify to waste. They have been and are still being taught the correct handling of tools. They have been and are still being taught blackboard drawing. During the past two and a half years they have repaired many articles of furniture; they have made several cupboards, and a few farm gates. They have constructed snow shelters on the girls' side and the boys' side of the school to protect the children from falling icicles from the roof. Moreover the boys have been the main workers in the erection of a three car garage last year, and at present are constructing a new poultry house. They are also engaged in making two fire doors on the stair-way landings leading to the dormitories.

No doubt it would be far better and more convenient if we had a resident manual instructor. I fail to see how we can do better, or how we can obtain a first class manual instructor on $400.00 a year. No doubt there are a few carpenters around who might do, but who have no technical school.
I have only words of praise for Mr. Manson, our Manual Instructor. Considering the short time at his disposal I think he has done excellent work with the boys under his charge.

Yours very truly,

P.J. Collins, M.S.
Principal
Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your 155-0-11 of December 14th, with reference to a statement by Mr. Inspector Barry in his School report of November 9th and 10th, to the effect that the services of Mr. J. S. Manson, as Manual Training Instructor at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, should be dispensed with.

It is, doubtless, true that a full time resident Manual Training Instructor would be preferable to a part time Instructor. If, however, financial limitations make this hope impossible then, in my own humble opinion, we are extremely fortunate to have Mr. Manson and, if any doubt is entertained by the Department as to what the Reverend Principal thinks of the man and his work, the enclosed letter, with which I fully agree, speaks for itself.

Yours faithfully,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a List of the Tools lost, and those saved, in the recent fire at the Kootenay Indian Residential School:

Also, copy of Principal Forbes letter accompanying the above list:

"Dear Sir:

As I pointed out in my report on our recent fire, at great risk to themselves, our Carpenter, Toby Moriceau, and Father Murray saved a number of tools from the burning Carpenter Shop. It was impossible to save anything from the Blacksmith Shop. We certainly could have saved more tools and flooring, had I allowed the boys to enter the burning Building (they volunteered to do so) but I knew that the Department would disapprove of my taking a risk in this matter. Those men named, have brought the tools out of the Building, and some of the Boys carried the tools to safety.

A fact which I would ask you to draw to the attention of the Department is, that while he could have saved tools belonging to himself, and to the Oblate Fathers, our Carpenter left them in order to save all tools possible belonging to the School.

Another point is, that immediately after coming here, I had the Blacksmith Shop cleared of a number of cardboard boxes, papers and rags. I also had a large pile of rubbish burned or removed from within fifteen feet of the Carpenter shop."

Dear Sir:

So that we can carry on our Manual Training, would you please ask the Department for about $100.00 to buy Lumber of various kinds, and sizes and nails. Classes are being held in a former chicken coop, but there is not sufficient light and there are various other disadvantages as you know.

It is unfortunate that the Blacksmiths Shop was burned at this particular time, as the boys could have learned a good deal of useful blacksmithing during seeding operations, mending broken implements etc., All this work has to be done in Town.

Would you please ask the Department for materials to re-build both Shops? With their Instructor, the boys can do the building as part of their training.

The Carpenter's shop measured 28'x26' and had as foundation a cement wall rising 3' above the ground. The walls, lumber, ran up another 3' to the roof which had an 8-12 pitch. A building of the same dimensions would be very acceptable; an earthquake some years ago damaged part of the foundations, but this can be repaired and the same foundations can be used.

As the Blacksmiths shop is used chiefly for repairing Farm Implements, and as part of the farm is owned by the Oblate Fathers, I feel that
I should mention that, while no rental (other than taxes) is charged by the Oblate Fathers for the use of this land, the produce is used directly and indirectly, for the benefit of the School.

The Dormitory floors are, with the exception of one, in the state reported by Inspector Barry and yourself. One floor was laid before the fire occurred. The Flooring for the other Dormitory and the Scutan paper were lost. Only the mails were saved. The Flooring was stored in the Carpenter Shop, which seemed a safe place.

Dear Sir:

I beg to quote the following from a recent letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School regarding the tools owned by the Manual Training Instructor and the Oblate Order lost when the Manual Training shop was destroyed by fire:

"I do not know whether you saw my report on the fire. In this report, I pointed out that, in order to save as much of the Government owned tools as possible, tools belonging to the carpenter and to the Oblates were deliberately sacrificed. As it was the carpenter, Father Murray and an Indian who were in the building and saved the tools, they could easily have saved the carpenter's and the Oblates' tools. If it is at all possible, Mr. Reifferscheid and Father Anthony would greatly appreciate being reimbursed for their loss. I enclose a list of these tools. Would you please return it as it is the only one I now have?"

It is highly doubtful if the Department would accept responsibility in a case of this kind because of the principle involved, nor am I prepared to recommend replacement of personal property from public funds. The matter, however, is being referred to the Department, as the Rev. Principal would no doubt wish me to do so.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,

Dear Sir:

Please inform the Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School that from September 1, 1941, the Department will make an allowance of $50.00 a month for the services of a vocational teacher. When forwarding the voucher for this allowance at the end of each quarter you should mark on this voucher -- "Pay from B.C. Special".

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Mr. Irwin:

You greatly surprised me when you told me that Mr. Hoey had pointed out to you that the grant for the Manual Trainer could not be paid to the Kootenay Indian School for the holiday months, as the Department had not done this in the past. The clue to the mystery appears to lie in the word Kootenay. In the other schools of which I have been in charge, the grant is paid for the twelve months, and so, naturally I expected that the case was the same here. I would submit that there are very good reasons either for the grant to be given for 12 months, or that the Department pay a Carpenter to make necessary repairs during the holidays. Naturally, if the Manual Trainer or the Carpenter did not work during the entire two months, the grant would cover only the days he worked. Last summer, the Manual Trainer worked steadily. You will recall that the Department supplied us with Flooring for the four dormitories, and that just before the floor was laid in the first dormitory, fire destroyed the rest of the lumber. The Department kindly supplied more flooring, but this did not come in time for the boys and their Instructor to lay the remaining floors before the holidays. There were holes in the floors, nails sticking out, splinters etc., so that especially if one had to get up at night, there was danger of injury. During the holidays the Manual Trainer did this, and other work.

When the Commissioner was here, I took him around to show him some urgently needed repairs. I forget the expression he used before we started out, but it indicated that he had inspected the school before, and knew how poorly it had been constructed. I showed him the basement floor (dining room for employees and children, long corridors, recreation halls, kitchen, pantries, etc., which sinks and rises as you walk...
on it, bulges in places etc. It should all be taken up and re-laid. Most of the flooring could be saved. The metal roof, (to save money for the Contractor I suspect) was put on with 1" nails instead of 2" nails and part of it is loose. All should be re-nailed. I thought that it was due to the building settling, but am told that it was due to an earthquake some years ago; that there are cracks in the cement walls of the building as well as in the foundation of the barn. There are also crevices between the cement walls of the main building which let in the cold and draughts. You, Mr. Doucet, and the Inspector and Commissioner agreed that the barn should be re-shingled. Then, I do not think that I exaggerate when I state that practically all the windows of the building are loose and let in the cold. We have also a Blacksmith shop and a Pig Pen to build, the Carpenter shop and two buildings occupied by employees and their families to complete, besides ordinary repairs.

In a word, we cannot catch up with the repairs during the school year, although the Manual Trainer with some boys and Father Anthony, an expert Carpenter, with boys, are busy during the year. May I point out that Father Anthony receives no pay for his work? I might add that I have been unable to pay the Sisters since June, 30th and that the Auditor remarked that I and the Disciplinarian had taken no salary. If the Department would agree to put this building and other buildings into shape so that the Manual Trainer would have only manual training and ordinary repairs, I would be quite satisfied with a grant for ten months.

Another point. Our pupilage has been cut from 90 to 83. This is only one of the things which, as I see it, hits a smaller school much harder than a larger one. Recently, someone said that compared
with the Kamloops school I was lucky; they had to maintain such a large staff, had lost the grant for so many more pupils than I etc. Well, suppose that the Kamloops school or any School of its size has a staff of 18, then, as they have at least three times as many pupils as I, I should have a staff of 6. Neither the Department nor I would be satisfied with that. We have seven Sisters, not to speak of the Principal, Boys' Disciplinarian, Mechanic, Manual Trainer, Farming Instructor and Father Anthony. A big school needs one Disciplinarian for the boys and so does a small one. The same is true with regard to a Manual Trainer, Mechanic, Farm Instructor, Disciplinarian for the girls, Matron, Nurse Principal etc.

It will now be realized why I inherited a debt of about $5200.00 and why I was not the first to be in the same boat. Thanks to $3500.00 from the Oblate Fathers I can carry on. As you know, the Oblate Fathers' farm is used for the benefit of the school. I cannot pay them for the hay, grain, vegetables etc.

Yours truly,

Signed G. Forbes...O.M.I...

It seems to me that, in comparison with some other schools, the pupils are not as bright as we would like to have them. Perhaps it would be truer to say that we seem to have a larger percentage of dull pupils than some other schools have.

The Department sent a Mr. Doucet here and we were under the impression that a course in manual training was to be sent us. We waited for this and, as it did not come, we have had the boys work with the manual trainer and with Father Anthony, an expert carpenter, building a carpenter shop, remodelling and repairing a dwelling house, laying floors and making odd repairs.
Ottawa, December 26, 1941.

Dear Father Forbes:

In your letter of the 19th instant you refer to manual training at the Kootenay Residential School. While it is true that Mr. Doucet visited your school some months ago, it was only with the intention of ascertaining what was being done. May I point out that the residential schools in British Columbia have received preferred treatment in regard to vocational training as compared with other Indian residential schools throughout Canada. With the exception of British Columbia, no funds are available either for paying for manual training instructors or providing tools and materials. We have to depend on the schools themselves to do this.

The vocational training plan which Mr. Doucet has outlined is being tried in residential schools in the province of Alberta for the current academic year, and it is not our intention to introduce this into British Columbia schools at the present time.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend George Forbes, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Dear Sir:

As the Department has a large sum of money invested in the buildings here, it naturally expects me to see that these buildings are kept in good repair. I think that I have tried to do even more than could reasonably be expected of me and, still, I find it impossible to catch up with necessary repairs. This is due, at least in part, to the fact that whoever built this school does not appear to have done as good a job as might have been expected. A few days ago, a plumber had to tear a few boards out of a wall. I understood him to say that he found only two nails in eight pieces of V-joint. I can show you boards in a floor which appear never to have had a nail in them. Indians, who were pupils here when the school opened, tell me that the wooden floors in the basement were laid over the cement (which was to have been the floor) because the pupils dug holes in the cement floors with tin cans. It is due, also, to the fact, as it seems to me, that realizing how pressed the Department was for money, the Principals did what they could with the money granted for repairs and with whatever other money they could scrape together and, then had to put off the rest of the repairs. I think that it is my duty to suggest what should be done to prevent further deterioration.

There is no use exaggerating and saying that, if repairs are not immediately made, the roof will fall on our heads because it won't. However, it is true that, unless we tackle the problem immediately, several buildings will rapidly deteriorate.

What should be done? As visitors come to the school or people pass by, they see the men's two buildings both of which are a disgrace. The foundations of one had rotted with the result that, although the building is only about 25 feet long, we had to raise one corner 18 inches. The shingles on this building need renewing, the building needs painting, the windows need attention, etc. A good deal of work has been done on this building already. The mechanic's residence is not finished. He and his family spent last winter in it although there is an opening, one inch or more by the width of the window, under each window. The building is not painted or finished inside or out.

As for the school, the stone steps leading to the main entrance (and used by all visitors) were not properly installed and, as a consequence, are broken, sinking, etc. As you enter the school, you notice that practically all the floors need varnishing. The treads on all interior staircases are badly worn. In places, the wainscoting is torn. The windows do not fit, green lumber having shrunk. Just how long the plumbing will hold out is hard to say. The floor in the boys' playroom needs renewing. Other floors need some repairing. Thanks to the lumber just given us by the Department, we shall have closets for the girls' clothes for the first time and partitions will be built between the Sisters' beds in their common dormitory. Other repairs are needed. When I have the facts, I will tell you of the need of replacing a rather dangerous makeshift. Before leaving this building, I should mention the two long cement sidewalks...
leading from the gate to the main entrance. I do not know whether the Department or the School had the work done, but the job was a poor one. The walks were laid on the top of the ground and cracked and broken with the heaving of the earth due to frost. The walks do not make a favorable impression on visitors.

Then, there is the barn. The two main doors in the loft, about 20 feet by ten, have been battered by the wind and only fragments remain. They and smaller doors need renewing. So do the planks on the floor of the section in which the horses are kept. As for the window panes missing, a rough guess of the number would be 100. The barn urgently needs reshingling and repainting.

And the pig pen. We have none. There are four hovels built of rough lumber and these do not make a favorable impression on those who come to see the pigs, buy them or have sows bred.

We have no blacksmith shop since ours burned. I once saw a letter in which it was stated that the Department did not believe the teaching of blacksmithing was practical. I believe it is, I forget the man's name, he is Isidore Dick's father-in-law, but he, who learned this trade at the Cariboo School, was blacksmith at the largest ranch in the Cariboo. I employed several graduates when I was in charge of the Cariboo School, and their training in blacksmithing came in very handy.

As I stated, none of these repairs is desperately urgent—except perhaps, the one I will mention in a future letter—but, if we let things go, the problem will be greater.

What do I suggest? A roundabout way of telling you is this. When, some years ago, I told an employee of the Department that $50.00 per month was hardly a just living wage for a manual trainer (provided that he was competent), I was rightly told that the Department was paying for an instructor in manual training and that, as the School used him as a carpenter, the School should pay the balance of his wages. That is reasonable. However, I do not feel that the Department can ask that I pay the balance of this man's wages and, in addition, have another carpenter on the staff when that is necessary for the maintenance of a Government-owned building. The Oblate Fathers understand our difficult position and they have done their share. In order to let the manual trainer devote his spare time to repairing the buildings here, they gave me a qualified carpenter to rebuild the carpenter shop and to build a piggery. I believe that they will supply most of the lumber as they did for another building. I nominally pay him a small salary ($40.00) and turn it back to the School. REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1943.

Kootenay Indian Residential School.

This School was inspected on Friday the 28th, and as usual was found to be in perfect condition. Basement, Dining Room, Kitchen, Sewing Room, Dormitories, Class Rooms etc., all were spotlessly clean.

Under the direction of Sister Henry, excellent progress is being made in the Sewing Room. Many useful pieces of clothing are being made. It is a training that should mean a great deal to these Indian girls in future years.

The same is true of the training received from the Dietitian in the preparing of meals; vegetables, meats, pastries etc., an excellent training that they will later need to know.

During the past month, the boys have been busy with Father Anthony, shingling the School Barn. It is the largest barn in the Kootenays, and their job is almost completed. This is the kind of practical manual training that should prove to be very useful.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1943.

Vocational Training;

A very fine example of the ability of our Indian boys to absorb practical and lasting benefits from their Manual Training course, is amply demonstrated in the completion of the shingling of the roof of the school stock barn. It is perhaps the largest building of its kind in the East Kootenays. It is a job well done, for which much credit is due to the Reverend Father Anthony, and his Indian boys.

The girls too, are being well and carefully taught in the art of fashioning and carrying on to completion the greater part of their own wardrobes as well as many other indispensable articles for home use.

Andrew Irwin,

Without mentioning it to the Department I have had our nurse give a course in home nursing to the older girls from Grade 4 up and it has proved fairly successful and I think that it should be continued and extended. This is just to warn you that I expect to ask for a little equipment in a few days.
Dear Mr. Macart:

Mr. R. Barre, employed here as instructor in Manual Training & Carpenter, has asked me whether I had any objection to his writing to you personally with a view to his getting a higher grade from the Department. (At his request, I wrote Mr. Barre's name to the local agent some time ago). I told him that I had no objection.

The following, sent confidentially, may give you a clearer view of the situation - so others, Mr. Barre does not appear to have given the whole story.

Two years ago, in May or June, I asked him (not quite) to do very good work for me in another school. He came here as carpenter & instructor. He replied that he would gladly come but was under contract & requested that I give a chance to his father who, as he said, was not a first class carpenter but was a good second class one. Without, however, any experience in manual training, I mentioned that the salary would be $50 per month, top after with board, etc.

The father came, while James away, & brought his wife and daughter although nothing had been paid by these two. Instead of giving him a room here, the person who was taking my place had to let him use, himself & family, an Oblate-owned house which they still use. This...
house needed repairing - Daniel did the material work. Mr. B., with some help from the boys, did the work. The house needs more land for a garden - he has added to it. The family is supplied with fuel (wood) for the winter. The family is supplied with fuel (wood) for the winter. The family is supplied with fuel (wood) for the winter.

The salary was $50.00 per month, but the Dept. raised it to $75.00 per month when I pointed out the urgent need of repairs to his work. School inspectors said that Mr. Barré could be moved to another job at an additional salary of $25.00 per month for two months or that, with no increase in Mr. Barré's salary, the Dept. might prefer to have the repairs done at its expense. The Dept. raised the grant and has been paying the man for two months' work whereas the former instructor was paid for only six months.

Among those to whom Mr. Barré spoke was, unfortunately, a man employed, some years ago, as an instructor in manual training. (I understand that the Inspector was not satisfied with him.) This man is paid to have told Mr. Barré what a good job he had at the Department's expense: the school can went to get him from town on Saturday mornings, after breakfast, took him home at 11:30. For the "work" he did between these hours, he got $5.00 per very short morning plus transportation to and from work. Why, Mr. Barré naturally asks himself, should he get less?
One answer might be that the former instructor got more than he deserved. Another might be that Mr. Barré has no papers or training as an instructor. At the time he accepted his work, he claimed credit to get two $500 plus house, etc., and he seems to have been able to pay off some small debts (26c, for instance) owed him upon his arrival by the person taking over place.

I should add that a less economical family would not have done this.

With the present stipends of per capita grants, I do not see how the school can raise his salary. In a little over 2½ years, my predecessor went into debt to the extent of $120. A few years before that, the Oblates had to assume a debt, here, of just over $100. This in April of this year, that the Oblates have taken a huge mortgage for six farms, food crops, of which is sold for which is donated to the school.

I am not sure to imply that Mr. Barré is not worth $700 to the school or that he is incompetent either as a carpenter or an instructor. It is possible that he might earn more, at least during the war, elsewhere. It would be difficult to get anyone to get as good a man at any other place, though perhaps impossible. It will certainly have a lot of work to do and he has certainly done a lot of work so far.

It might be paying his building for his department. It might be easy advantage to increase the grant. To the department's advantage. If we were able to make a deal more, that Mr. Barré does; it will cost us, if we let the building deteriorate, it will cost us too much to put it in its condition as it should be in.
I would like to start the career in manual training, which you kindly sent us, towards the end of this month. I have suggested to Mr. Barrie that he let you know what tools will be needed - or, perhaps, you will prefer to send what your experience suggests should be sent.

A week ago tomorrow, I married a widower to a widow. His great grandchildren are in their 20's. Last spring I was called to administer his last sacrament to him. They removed his eye and appear to have made a new man of him.

With kind personal regards,

[Signature]

P. Forbes Oriel
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Doucet:

Extract from Inspector Frederickson's Report
on his visit to the Kootenay Residential School.

Vocational Training:

Possibly the term "vocational" is a misnomer as the use of the expression implies the possibility of a variety or choice of variety of future vocations. This, unhappily, does not apply to the eventual pursuits of Indian boys and girls whose opportunities appear distinctly limited.

The "manual training" programme is not being applied with effectiveness. It appears that there is little planned organization for the use of the "shop" and such facilities as it offers. The building itself is very well planned and constructed but is poorly equipped. While the poor equipment is a handicap it should be utilized more completely than is apparent. The manual training instructor is untrained and not well informed as to the purposes of his position. He is a "practical" man who spends too much of his time doing odd jobs and too little instructing the boys. Very little has been done to follow the vocational programme as outlined and no badges have been awarded.

Some effort has been made to interest and instruct some of the boys in the care of poultry and some badges have been awarded. Possibly this enterprise has not reached full effectiveness as the general conditions of the poultry pens is not good.

Scientific and organized interests in swine and cattle has not progressed very far. While the boys are good milkers most of their work appears to consist of chores.

A garden plan has been made and the garden planted but the boys seem to have had little share in the planning. There is no pride of ownership or possession - an educational necessity.

The girl's courses are better planned and organized. Various groups rotate monthly in the sewing-room, laundry-room, kitchen, etc. The girls work well and
cheerfully but, unfortunately, have to spend too much time in performing institutional chores such as mending, washing preparing vegetables, etc., under conditions which do not approach home experiences. While instruction is given in sewing and dress-making the instruction is severely limited and is not calculated to create interest and knowledge in desirable dressing habits. Although kitchen and laundry experiences are gained there seems to be no direct progressive teaching of nutrition, textiles, etc. As almost one hundred meals are served three times each day the difficulties in the way of tuition are apparent yet I think some directed effort could be made in giving the girls some responsibility in the planning of the meals and in teaching them food values. In fact, if the education they receive is to possess any sustained interests this must be done.

The sisters are making a sincere attempt to institute the "badge system" but if this system were supplemented by a good professional library and, if possible by professional training the programme would be less mechanistic.

Both boys and girls should be encouraged to wear their badges which should be presented with proper ceremony in order to emphasize pride of ownership.

Too much of the so-called Vocational Training is devoted to repair and maintenance. While much of this is necessary, improved organization and professional knowledge would do a great deal to effect a progressive programme. While it is difficult to obtain skilled instructors, the teachers in charge should do more to acquaint themselves with professional objectives. Both boys and girls should have at least five hours a week of directed and objective vocational training and this should be rigidly adhered to.

A definite and aggressive policy to implement the Vocational Training plan as outlined should be effected. This plan can be modified to suit conditions but the mechanistic pursuit of it is not stimulating. The children should be encouraged to win and to wear their badges and these should be awarded at appropriate ceremonies. Pride of possession and a sense of "belonging to" are essential in motivation.

(Sgd) C.J. Frederickson.
Ottawa, July 14, 1944.

Dear Father Forbes:

We are in receipt of a lengthy report from Inspector Frederickson regarding his last inspection of the Kootenay Residential School.

For your information I inclose a copy of his remarks regarding vocational training and I would appreciate your comments.

We note with regret that the Inspector thinks that the badges are not given to the winners at a public gathering. I feel that he must be mistaken in this regard because definite instructions to this effect were issued to the Principals some time ago.

The Inspector also refers to the lack of tools. It is rather difficult for us to realize this statement. I inclose for your information a copy of a list of tools which are at Kootenay. We feel, that if these are in the vocational training shop there should be sufficient.

I presume that part of the difficulty is due to the fact that Mr. Barre is not fully qualified to carry out the work. I would appreciate any effort you make to have Mr. Barre consider our instructions and put them into effect more fully than he has been doing.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have just received your letter, dated July 22, 1944, here at Mission where I am attending the annual retreat.

Mrs. Fredericks kindly gave me a copy of her report. She was greatly misinformed on certain points. Take, for instance, the awarding of badges.

1. The badges awarded to the girls were presented by Mr. Inspector Coleman in the presence of Mr. Indian Agent Irwin & all the pupils. I was called out just as the badges were to be presented but I understood that Mr. Inspector Coleman made an appropriate speech.

2. I myself awarded the badges to the boys, in the senior classroom, in presence of their teachers & the girls' classes in the higher grades. I did my best to say what I felt should be said.

By whom, I do not know. I have noticed the boys wearing

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Their badges during the holidays & also ours of the girls doing the same. This is the only girl I have seen.

As I am away from Crowbrook, I cannot say what tools we have in the shop. Unless I am mistaken, the Inspector's meaning is that, compared to public schools, in Crowbrook, for instance, which he inspects, our equipment is far below theirs. We have only Carpenter Tools (with a few blacksmith tools) whereas the public school has tools for other branches of Manual Training.

I do not expect to have Mr. Barrie at Crowbrook next term. I suppose said that he & his boys were doing a "practical" job (sharing being a small cottage) during the Inspector's visit. While it is true that the Vocational Course has not been followed closely, I would like to stress the fact that, in fours or fives, about 20 boys have spent 3 hours or more per week in the shop.

With regard to the implications of the note on care of poultry, I cannot agree with the Inspector. In this & all other matters involving the preparation or alteration for him, the poultry houses are cleaned on Saturdays, the dirt that comes on Saturday is as far as I can recall. The droppings are not removed daily by us or by many families as I know.
With regard to the garden, I told the Inspector that I had planned it so that the pupils could visit. I did not tell him that I had given lectures to the pupils (in Grade IV) on the need of a garden for the pupils (in Grade IV) on the need of a garden for Indians; on the site of a garden; on what we were going to plant, why, etc... I do not find it practical to have individual plots for each pupil — this would be practical if they stayed at the School all the time. The garden was growing in July and August, and no garden may have been the pride of ownership. However, the Inspector failed to note it that there were two gardens — one looked after by the boys and one cared for by the girls — and there was plenty of real rivalry between the two, and, in fact, a sense of ownership.

Mr. Fredericksen is a well-qualified man interested in his work. He wants more modern methods and more books in the School.

A point to be noted is that, while there are a few exceptions, the Indians appear to be a good deal behind the Indians I knew at the Christie School, Kamloops, Williams Lake, etc.

Yours very truly,

P. Foster

Dear Mr. Doucet:

It was suggested to me by the former Principal, Rev. G. Forbes, that I contact you as regards the teaching of Agriculture in this school.

I have just been appointed Principal and I am interested in giving a course in Agriculture and Animal Husbandry to the boys of this school. I would be glad to receive any information you can give me in this matter. Is there a course of study outlined by the Dept.? If so, I would be glad to have it. Any books, or pamphlets which you suggest as a guide will be most welcome.

Does the Dept give a grant to encourage the development of Vocational Agriculture among our Indians? If so, to what extent.

From my observations to date it would seem that there is a great need for more Agricultural development here. Anything you can do to aid us in this endeavour will be highly appreciated.

Trusting to hear from you at your earliest convenience,

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, November 13th, 1945.

Dear Father Kelly:

Returning from an extensive trip to Manitoba and Saskatchewan I find your letter awaiting me.

We have as yet no special course in Agriculture and Animal Husbandry except the basic operations for gardening which, I believe, the school has. I am, however, enclosing another copy for your information.

You will be receiving in a short time some books dealing with Agriculture. I would suggest that you obtain copies of pamphlets issued by the Provincial Department of Agriculture. Although these books are coached in a language not readily understood by the pupils they contain valuable information.

There is no special grant given for the encouragement of Agriculture among our Indians. If, however, you have some special plan or some special recommendation I am sure that the Welfare Division would consider suggestions sympathetically.

Should there be any way in which I could serve you I will be only too pleased to do so.

Yours truly,

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Rev. G.F. Kelly,
Kootenay Residential School,

Dear Mr. Phalen:

Re: Annual Training Grant.

I have not yet during this school year received any grant for annual training. No doubt this is my own fault as I was of the impression that it would be paid without a separate application for it each year. However I enquired from Father Forbes and he said I should have written for it.

This year's course has been devoted for the most part to carpentry work in the school building. In accordance with the approved kindergarten program tables have been made for the juniors to use instead of desks. A number of easels have also been made for art work. A table and benches were made for the sewing room. New doors, a masonite backing for the basins, and other repairs were done by the boys under the direction of the annual trainer. Besides such activities they have been instructed in the basic operations as outlined for the various years in accordance with the directions supplied by the Dept. Shoe repairing, painting, and some blacksmith work have also been directed by the annual trainer.

I hope that even at this late date you will be able to arrange for the usual grant so that these and further undertakings may continue to receive their proper attention.

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly
Principal.

I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of March 3rd concerning the allowance for manual training instruction at the above school and forward herewith the completed form as requested.

I am not in a position to make a recommendation as to an increase in the allowance already made at this school as I have not visited it and do not know the number of pupils receiving manual training instruction, nor am I in a position to say what the calibre of Mr. McKinnon's instruction is.

Previous reports on this school indicate that in the past very little manual training instruction was given to the pupils and the greater part of the instructor's time was taken up with maintenance work about the building. However, it is understood that the Department has records which show the amount of time devoted to manual training and the number of pupils receiving this instruction.

With regard to a general increase in the salaries of manual training instructors I do not believe it is possible
to set out a policy which would be applicable to all schools as these vary greatly in size. For example, the Kamloops Residential School which has a school population of over 300 at the present time might use profitably a full-time manual training instructor, whereas the Kootenay Residential School which has an enrolment of slightly over 100 can use a manual training instructor only part-time. In the latter case the remainder of the instructor's time is usually devoted to maintenance work about the school.

It seems to me that in making allowances for manual training instruction at these schools the following factors should be taken into consideration:

(1) Qualifications of the instructor.
(2) His experience.
(3) Number of pupils receiving instruction and the time devoted to this work.

In the absence of the Commissioner I have discussed this matter with the Inspector of Agencies, Mr. Coleman, and he is in agreement with me. However you will probably wish to discuss this with Major MacKay who is at present in Ottawa.

Re: Manual Training,
Kootenay Indian Residential School

With reference to the above mentioned vocational training branch of our school and its possible direct bearing on any future housing program in the Kootenay Agency, I have attempted to formulate some constructive plan of approach to the vital subject of providing adequate homes for the Indians of this Agency and respectfully submit the following suggestion.

I would concentrate on training the older boys at the school in manual training with a view to hiring a good carpenter to supervise several of these boys in a long term construction project, this trained group to build a house complete. The success of the first building project would determine the feasibility of continuing until adequate housing is provided over the entire Agency.

Power tools have become a necessity in modern construction. Practically all material used in a house can be cut accurately with these tools and I would suggest that such equipment be acquired at the school to be made available for construction on the St. Mary's Reserve.

I am enclosing an estimate on the cost of power tools as supplied by Parks Hardware Ltd., which in turn was supplied to them by their Vancouver Wholesale house.

Some direct method of approach to the housing situation will have to be arrived at and I would be pleased to have your views on my approach, or any other
suggestions you may have in this connection. My observations lead me to believe that the mere providing of building materials to individual Indians for constructing homes a waste of both money and material.

Re: Manual Training at Kootenay Indian Residential School.

With reference to your letter of June 23rd regarding suggestions by Inspector Davey, that he is of the opinion that a circular saw with moveable blade is more suitable for instructional purposes than an 8" tilting table saw in respect to safety to student operators, that a jointer would possibly be of more use than a wood lathe and the possible use of electric motors in preference to the 2½ h.p. gasoline engine I recommended.

A Delta, tilting table saw with locking devices and saw guard should not present undue exposure to accident when set up properly.

In recommending a wood lathe, I had in mind a tool that forms the most important factor in student interest in manual training. A jointer would undoubtedly be more practical and I had hoped to add this equipment at the first opportunity.

A jig saw is also important in student interest.

A deep forge for welding and hardening tools is another piece of equipment I had in mind; there are many uses for such around a farm, as repairing wagons and farm equipment, shoeing horses, etc.

The above tools should be of medium heavy quality as I have in mind heavier construction than ordinarily is met in a Public school manual training.
establishment.

The question of power has proved difficult to recommend. If hydro power becomes available in the future our problem is solved, at present additional wiring would be necessary to connect the manual training shop with the main school. This is not altogether practical either as the main school diesel would have to operate continuously to provide power and the power so provided would require D.C. motors, which are practically unobtainable at this time. A gasoline motor and line shaft would undoubtedly prove unwieldy, but would provide an independent source of power.

The Rev. Father Kelly has already applied for a fully qualified instructor for this coming term and it would be a great stride forward if some power machinery were made available.

The B. C. Equipment Co., Vancouver, have been giving satisfactory service to many manual training schools in B. C. and could probably supply sounder recommendations in this regard.

J. S. Dunn,
Indian Agent.

May 22, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We delayed answering your letter of April 19th, file 5-11-6 (155) enclosing requisition for manual training and domestic science equipment at the Kootenay School until Mr. Doucet returned from an inspection trip.

Mr. Doucet visited this school some time ago and is under the impression that at that time the school had a reasonable supply of equipment for manual training. I note that Inspector Davey states that the five page requisition is in accordance with the suggested list published by the Department of Education in Victoria.

However, before authorizing the purchase, we would like to be assured that all the items are absolutely essential at the Kootenay School. We would also like to know the approximate cost.

Careful consideration has also been given to the request for material and other supplies for a domestic science course. Are we to understand that a special room is available so that unit instruction can be given to the girls taking the domestic science course at the Kootenay School? Has the school conducted a special domestic science course previously or are they just starting such programme. In either event we would like to know who is in charge and her qualifications.

Bernard F. Neary
PP/MGD

Dear Mr. Dunn:

Please find attached a requisition for material to begin our course in pottery. This is a course I have been anxious to begin for the past two years as I feel it would be very profitable to the children and can be developed into a paying industry after school days. We have on the staff, Sister Paul of the Cross, who taught this course in the Shubenacadie Indian School in Nova Scotia. She is fully competent to handle such a course as she has had many years of experience in the work as well as having received instruction from professionals in the art of pottery making.

I understand that our Indian Commissioner, Mr. Arneil, is familiar with the type of work she was doing in the Shubenacadie School and any further references which the Dept. wishes regarding her ability can be obtained from that Institution. I feel that we should be making use of her ability to teach this course while she is here rather than having her talents remain unused. Last year, at the instigation of School Inspector Fredrickson, she lectured during the Teachers Convention on this subject and following that the High School in Kimberley took up the work. She has been giving them some assistance and direction. I feel that it is too bad to let another school take our rightful place in this art when we could be doing so much with it.

Our local clay has been tested and found suitable for this work. You are probably aware that the Post Office building and the Hanson Block in Cranbrook are built from brick made quite near our school. There is no doubt that we have an ample clay deposit for this work and should with time build this course into something definitely worthwhile culturally and financially.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd) G. F. Kelly, O.M.I.
Principal.

Re: Proposed Pottery Course, Kootenay Residential School.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter and a requisition for supplies submitted to me by the Rev. Father G. F. Kelly, Principal of our Residential School, relative to inauguration of a pottery course for the Indian pupils.

With but few exceptions our Kootenay Indians have been unable to successfully compete with white labour in local industry, being confined to farming their land on the reserves, engaging in a little trapping and, only when other help is scarce, working in the woods.

Their natural ability in arts and crafts is of a high caliber with local buckskin work recognized by expert dealers as the finest on the North American continent. It would, therefore, appear that every effort to enlarge on their natural talent should be encouraged. And if the school can assure us of the services of Sister Paul of the Cross as an instructor over a necessary period of time, I would respectfully recommend that consideration be given toward inauguration of this pottery course for the school pupils.

Dear Mr. Dunn:

In reply to yours of the 17th inst., regarding the qualifications of the Instructress of Domestic Science in this school, I wish to report as follows. The Sister in charge of this course has not a certificate in this work but has had several years of practical experience. She was cook here for three years and in a boarding school in Nova Scotia for five. Since we are receiving no additional salary grant for her work in this course it hardly seems fair to expect us to incur the expenses of a degree or extra-curriculum studies in this matter. Previous to '44 Domestic Science was taught here, as in many other places, in the school kitchen, which as we all know has decided disadvantages. During the year '44 a room was set aside and equipped in so far as the school felt able to equip it. To my knowledge no grant or requisition for material was ever received towards this project. As a result the equipment is not up to what it should be nor is there sufficient of it. However if the Dept. feels that the expenditure requested cannot be allowed under the circumstances we can very easily revert to the former practise of having the children learn their lessons in cooking in the school kitchen though I feel it would be detrimental to them.
The girls have taken very readily to this course and already I have seen evidences of the use they have made of it at home during the summer vacation as well as in the housekeeping of some of the graduates.

As regards the building of cupboards instead of the kitchen cabinet I have tried in vain to interest any of the local contractors in the project due to over abundance of work. However I drew up a plan of what I felt would be suitable and discussed it with Mr. Linton Lundy, who is already employed to make certain alterations in a classroom and one dormitory here. He figured that about fifty-five dollars worth of lumber and material would satisfy our needs. If an allowance for this much would be granted by the Dept. I would personally arrange for the building of same.

Trusting this will clarify the matter and that we may have an early reply on our requested requisition, I remain,

Sincerely Yours,

(sgd) G. F. Kelly, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have spent the last week at the Kootenay Residential School.

I find that we need some good Milch Cows very badly there. The present stock seems to be rather run down, and the Principal of the School feels that the financial condition of the School will not warrant them purchasing new stock.

I am therefore, making an appeal to you for assistance in this matter. I can assure you that both Inspector Col. Pragnell, and Mr. E.H.Small, Indian Agent approve of this move.

In the past year there has been some dissatisfaction among the parents of the school children, they claiming that the children do not get enough milk, and I feel that the purchase of about twelve cows will eliminate this difficulty.

Trusting that you can see your way to authorize the purchase of this stock, and so assist us in this matter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose copy of a letter I have just received from Rev. M. Lepine, Principal of Kootenay Residential School at Cranbrook. The letter is self explanatory, and the importance of having plenty of milk for the children is constantly in my mind.

As you know, until the arrival of the new Principal, there was considerable trouble over the food supply at this school, and I am given to understand that things are much better now. It, however, sticks in my mind that the Missionaries running this school should do something for themselves, and not depend entirely upon the good will of the Department. I may be wronging them, as they may be at considerable expense in straightening matters out there, but unless I see their books I cannot say. All I know is that other schools, as a whole, supply themselves with their own cows and the Department has already given this school five cows.

In order to initiate the idea of a little self help there, I think that, if I were the Department, I should be inclined to offer to give them a couple more cows if they themselves will also buy two equally good ones at the same time. It is with some diffidence that I offer this suggestion, as I do not want the school to slip back again into its old ways, as I have had trouble enough in straightening things out as it is.

Yours truly,

Geo. S. Pragnell

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have written you an official letter with regard to the proposed temporary alterations at St. Mary's School at Mission, but I think it advisable to drop you also a few personal lines on the subject.

Upon going to New Westminster last Tuesday, I found Rev. Jno. Welch there, as apparently he had been informed of my proposed visit, as I had written to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt on the 5th giving him the information that you considered it more preferable to construct outside class-rooms than dormitories. Not having the correspondence which had taken place with regard to the alleged dangerous situation at this School, I asked what changes had taken place there during the past two years and was informed that there had been very few with the exception of the creation of a small additional dormitory for the boys and an outside class-room for the girls, a number of additional female pupils now sleeping in the old sewing room in the main building, which, as reported, is heated by hot water from the central heating plant and lighted by electricity. In view of this information, I then asked in what respect the fire hazard was greater than it had been in 1911, when I inspected the building to see if this school complied with the regulations sufficient to warrant the increased grant payable at that time, as I had a suspicion that the School authorities had been endeavouring to make you believe that the fire hazard was much greater than it really is. I pointed out to the Reverend Father and the Agent that though we knew very well that the buildings were old and ought to and could be renewed as soon as possible, but as the Department did not own the land, it would be impossible to put up new buildings at Mission until some definite arrangement had been made with the Order of Oblate Fathers about the site. I also endeavoured to get some information as to why the acclaim about the fire hazard, but could not get it. I then decided to visit the School to satisfy myself and the results of my investigation are contained in the official letter referred to.

On the way back to New Westminster, I interrogated Indian Agent Daunt as to what had taken place and he informed me that the Fire Marshall had made a very adverse report about the buildings, saying there were death traps, the fire hazard being great, and in general that they should be renewed. This report, I learned, was made by the Fire Marshall at the request of the Reverend Father Mailliard, the Principal, and I feel almost certain that this action was taken with the idea of stampeding the Department into building a new school at once.

Of course, I can not be certain on this point, but I have a very grave suspicion that such was the case.

Dear Doctor Scott,

I have written you a full official letter in connection with the land at Mission, but there are some points in connection with this matter which I think it better that I should inform you on personally.

You will remember in 1922 we decided to assist the Oblate Order by the payment of taxes on Lot 2, Group 3, on which the School is situated and the whole area is used for the benefit of the School. Taxes at that time were $468.50 per annum and a refund has been made to the Principal of the School annually ever since that time. The last voucher sent in by the New Westminster office was for $445.90. While I was at Mission City recently, upon making investigations with the municipal officer, Mr. Kerr, the collector, informed me that the whole of Lot 2 had been exempted from taxation by the Corporation of the District of Mission ever since 1925, and he opened up his books to show that this was the case. I immediately produced the tax receipt which the Reverend Principal had forwarded to the New Westminster office, copies of which will be found on the vouchers at Ottawa, showing that they stated definitely that this receipt was for taxation on Lot 2. The assessor was immediately sent for and he concurred in what the collector had stated with regard to Lot 2 being non-taxable, but could not give a very satisfactory explanation as to why the same situation did not exist in Lot 3. I am surprised, therefore, that the Reverend Father Maillard, Principal of the School, has been forwarding these tax receipts on to the New Westminster office expecting the Department to pay the various amounts that we have been doing. Very Rev. and dear Father,

In compliance with your request of the 16th inst., I beg to submit the following statement regarding taxes paid by St. Mary's Mission, at Mission City, B.C. Part of these taxes were refunded by the Indian Dept.

The first and second year I was in charge of Mission School I paid over $1100.00 in taxes, i.e. 10% of all our revenue. The Deputy Minister called on me during the second Summer of my incumbency. He agreed to refund part of the taxes. On the same occasion it was agreed that the Oblates were to give five acres of land for building purposes, and the Dept. was to buy some 135 acres. The Deputy Minister insisted in securing not less than 140 acres. A board of arbitration was to be appointed to set value upon the buildings, the land, the implements and the live stock. The Oblate Provincial did not know the most suitable location for school work. Later on I succeeded in getting exemption of part of the property. I fought the case with the Municipality for over a year. The taxes were such that I could not carry on the work. Then the school received only $140.00 per head, i.e. 40 cents per day per child. Food and clothes were dearer than at present and I had some ten non-paying children. After obtaining exemption of part of the school property, I continued sending the tax bill to the Indian Dept. at Ottawa, though I knew very well that taxes had been refunded on the other portion of land. We must remember that the land to be donated and to be purchased by the Dept. had not been agreed upon. Moreover the whole property was used for school purposes. We were cutting our wood on the portion of land taxes on which were refunded by the Dept. Raspberries, strawberries, loganberries and other products came from the same land. We never sold anything and we used everything for the school children. The Dept. was getting the full use of the land. There never was any kind of collusion. And no matter what may be said, there was no act of dishonesty on my nor the slightest thought of defrauding the Indian Dept. which I have served faithfully and quite successfully.

Yours sincerely,
