Dear Sir,

In reference to your recent request for particulars relating to the milk supply of the school, I beg to submit the following details.

Of the fourteen cattle listed as milch cows on the December inventory, two were too old for further use and were butchered during the winter months, one of the heifers has freshened and the others are supposed to freshen soon. Nine of the cows have freshened this spring.

At the present time ten cows are milking and we receive approximately twenty-five gallons of milk per day. This will be increased considerably when the pasture becomes good shortly.

All the milk is used in the school and all milk products are used in the school. The general condition of the cows is good, although they were in very poor condition when we took charge of them in December.

Owing to the general ill-health of the school children it is desirable that they have all the milk that they need all the year. During the winter months we received only about four gallons per day, which was inadequate for a school having a very high percentage of tubercular children. I would like to have ten to fifteen cows milking at all times of the year. I think that if we could do this we would see a remarkable improvement in the health of the children.

I would recommend the heavier variety of cattle because when the smaller Jerseys are too old they are very light for beef purposes, nor are their steers heavy enough, which is an important consideration for the school. Moreover, unless these Jerseys are fed concentrated milk producing foods they produce very little more milk than the heavier varieties.

Trusting this will give you an explanation of my request, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

There are a number of very fine herds of registered Ayrshire cattle in East Kootenay, and both the Reverend Principal and myself are strongly of the opinion that if additional cows are to be purchased it would be much better to have Ayrshires than any other breed. The big Consolidated Mining & Smelting Company's herd at Marysville consists principally of registered and grade Ayrshires, and the herd at the Dominion Experimental Farm at Windermere is also composed of registered Ayrshires. Dear Sir:

As requested by you, I visited the Ogilvy-Wills farm near Fairmont Springs on October 24th and examined their herd of purebred Ayrshire cows with a view to selecting eight animals to be purchased for the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

I consider these cows are of very fine type, and should develop into good animals. As they are young, the oldest one being five years of age, many of the younger heifers, with proper care, should make good sized and most useful matured cattle as foundation stock to eventually develop for the school an all registered herd. Their breeding shows that they are from a good milking strain and should be very suitable for the purpose aimed at in furnishing rich and wholesome milk for the school children.

I have been very particular in examining these cows for anything in the way of diseases or defects in their udder and I find they are in good health and apparently free from all contagious disease and udder defects. I am informed that the tuberculosis test has been applied within the past year with no reactors in the herd. Their condition as to flesh at the present time is fair, and with ordinary care these cows should winter in good condition.

When making the examination I noticed the heifer "Culdare's Bluebell", that is suckling a calf at present, is in rather poor condition, and would strongly recommend that "Culdare's Holly", another purebred heifer some months younger and also suckling a calf, should be substituted, owing to the fact of her being in much better condition and larger, with the calf superior to that of Bluebell, indicating that she is feeding the calf either a greater quantity of milk or milk of better quality. This is the only change I would recommend in the eight cows previously selected by Mr. A. L. Hay.

Trusting the above will meet with the approval of the Department, I am,

Yours very truly,

J. W. Rutledge, V.S.

Dear Sir:

As requested by you, and also being directed by Doctor E. L. Stone when in Cranbrook, I visited the Kootenay Indian Residential School on October 30th and again on November 2nd, to apply the Tuberculin Test to the herd of twenty-eight cows at that place. I am pleased to say that the test showed the herd to be free from tuberculosis, there being no reactors.

I also examined the barn and premises, and would recommend a few alterations. I have suggested that the yard be cleaned up and the manure drawn away.

The barn, which was painted inside a number of years ago, should be repainted, as it would be much better than to apply whitewash. Also, there are some alterations that are necessary in the barn, as they are short of stall room for the cows. There are six box stalls situated at one end of the barn where pigs and young calves are now being kept. I would suggest that these be removed and cow stalls put in their place. This would be more satisfactory as it is most unsanitary to keep pigs in a cow barn. I would also suggest that if pigs are to be kept a piggery should be built that would be suitable for the purpose.

The fencing around the barn is in bad shape; the posts are rotten and the wire is down.

I am pleased to say that the live stock at the School farm is in very fine condition, the pigs, poultry and cattle are thrifty and in good health, and the new cows add considerably to the appearance of the herd.

Trusting this will meet with the approval of the Department, I am,

Yours very truly,

J. W. Rutledge, V.S.
